I'm fine changing it to == since this is [[]] instead of just [] (which under some shells could end up using the /bin/[ symlink to /bin/test or what have you), but regardless -eq is entirely incorrect in this context."}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2017-11-21 04:23:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-29 01:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-05 19:36:42.000000000', 'message': 'Use = for string comparisons

Change I384e4c376076051e7a4a8b2d704107cbe3ac08ad introduced
comparisons of $DEVSTACK_PROJECT_FROM_GIT against a couple of
hardcoded string values in a bash [[ ]] expression, but incorrectly
used the -eq integer comparison operator. This seems to work under
normal circumstances, but actually breaks if the string value of the
variable contains a "." since the equivalence test tries to fail
early if it detects what it thinks is a float value (because it's
intended only for integers). Instead of -eq use = for string
comparisons here, because that's what the POSIX test(1) utility
mandates.

Change-Id: If33d7aea9142e650b57c0f58c14e2a4434e30bf0
'}]
commit_message:
Use = for string comparisons

Change I384e4c376076051e7a4a8b2d704107cbe3ac08ad introduced
comparisons of $DEVSTACK_PROJECT_FROM_GIT against a couple of
hardcoded string values in a bash [[ ]] expression, but incorrectly
used the -eq integer comparison operator. This seems to work under
normal circumstances, but actually breaks if the string value of the
variable contains a "." since the equivalence test tries to fail
early if it detects what it thinks is a float value (because it's
intended only for integers). Instead of -eq use = for string
comparisons here, because that's what the POSIX test(1) utility
mandates.

Change-Id: If33d7aea9142e650b57c0f58c14e2a4434e30bf0

commit_message:
[QoS] Add info about rate limiting on router's ports

Qos policy with bandwidth limit rules can be applied on router's
gateway ports to limit only if veth are used to connect it to
namespaces.
This commit updates "ovs_use_veth" config option help message and
qos docs to add such info there.

Change-Id: I69e78bc125d430c933f7576d05308030789cee0a
Related-Bug: #1732852

commit_message:
Leverage oslo.log default log levels

oslo.log provides defaut log levels in [1], it's good to keep
consistent across OpenStack services, just add extra levels
that Ironic needs as we did in other projects.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.log/blob/master/oslo_log/_options.py#L19

Change-Id: I46abb7b13204d7f0234ae27b1d3f743fb1d14bf7

recheck - when will it be deprecated? do you have a link to read about this change and for us to see if there are other backwards incompatible changes? 

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2017-10-31 14:55:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

messages: [{'account_id': 25571, 'date': '2017-11-17 04:42:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25254, 'date': '2017-11-23 05:24:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17151, 'date': '2017-11-23 12:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25695, 'date': '2017-11-27 04:05:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21224, 'date': '2017-11-29 02:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 04:42:38.000000000', 'message': "Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html

Change-Id: I8ff60cc3793aea723a77d1b47a0f68c6c5c6ec62
"}]
commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html

Change-Id: I8ff60cc3793aea723a77d1b47a0f68c6c5c6ec62

commit_message:
Use qemu-img in bindep

The qemu-img-ev package comes from the virtualization sig backports.
These stopped getting installed with
I747c2b8754effbc6ec82af3bf7543fd9599a6c14.  I believe that this is
really installing these dependencies for dib to convert the image, and
that works with the standard qemu-img package.

Change-Id: I0c09c54f7ace4ac28942b733cbc6dfe42436ecdc

commit_message:
Remove ceilometer client class

The ceilometer client has been retired upstream and the class has been
previously deprecated. Since the package may be going away, we need to
remove the client class.

commit_message:
Checkout from -eol tag on zuul v2.x

Doing the same as commit I344d8fdded9b7d5385fcb41b699f1352acb4cda7,
but for third-party CIs which are not using zuul v3 yet.

Core projects like keystone, cinder, glance and neutron do not have
anymore the stable/newton branch, but they have the newton-eol tag.
So this will allow to run nova stable/newton patches.

Change-Id: I49438cb7a0e209da61ae0c35d536ac2c2ea5ec59

> The CLI makes use of kbits, but kbps is stored in the database. Is

not exactly. It is same value in CLI and database. Problem is only with units in parameter name. It should be kbit as it is really value in kilobytes but in neutron-server (and db) parameter is named with kbps (kilobits per second) which is not correct.'}, {'account_id': 25943, 'date': '2017-11-10 00:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 25943, 'date': '2017-11-10 01:04:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

thanks for Slawek's comments addressed abouot "--max-burst-kbits" (output consistent with input used on CLI command(s)) , I'm good with this proposal. commit_message:
docs: Correct various mistakes in QoS doc

OpenStack client doesn't display "Created" after
create operation.

Also this patch corrects an erroneous ingress rule update command by
changing "--max-burst-kbps" to "--max-burst-kbits".

Finally, the output of several commands is corrected.

Change-Id: I93aac4a5f293919b3fd8acf1c0310f6864004ee0
Closes-Bug: #1730896

subject: Fix failure in devstack single node deployment of congress
messages:
[{'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2017-11-17 06:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-17 09:34:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Anusha!

Thanks for getting on this. Do you have a link or logs handy for the failure experienced? I'm concerned about whether it means the in-memory way of deploying no longer works. We'd like to support the in-memory way of deploying (no rabbitMQ) if possible."}, {'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2017-11-17 09:51:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Eric, Actually single-node deployment is not tested on gate. Today I did latest devstack installation, I found the failure. 
>> I'm concerned about whether it means the in-memory way of deploying no longer works. We'd like to support the in-memory way of deploying (no rabbitMQ) if possible.
Actually in current code, we not setting transport url if multi-process deployment is False, code seems to be commented out .. https://github.com/openstack/congress/blob/master/devstack/plugin.sh#L69 , dont remember why. But kombu+memory is only for testing , so isn't it better to use actual driver instead, as they use in production? That's the reason I added this ."}, {'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2017-11-17 10:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Eric, I just tested with  in-memory ( kombu+memory:////) it works fine. But explicit setting of transport_url is needed in either case. Otherwise its failing.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-17 15:45:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ahh got it thanks for checking!

Instead of setting it explicitly, can we instead set the default config here?
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/congress/tree/congress/common/config.py#n32

Something like this but with a default value for kombu.
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.messaging/tree/oslo_messaging/transport.py#n44

Because ideally default single process deployment doesn't require setting transport_url or running rabbitMQ."}, {'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2017-11-22 05:39:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

>> Instead of setting it explicitly, can we instead set the default >> config here?
>> http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/congress/tree/congress/common/config.py#n32

I don't think its good idea to set in congress repo, as its not congress specific option, instead can we update in documentation? 
And also, I couldn't find any official documentation on kombu+memory driver as its official supported/deprecated details, so before adding to documentation , we better make sure its well supported.

I can update the same in devstack config though, if you feel its better, as devstack is only dev purpose/not production setup."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-22 07:30:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Anusha!

The reason why I suggested setting it as a default value is this: The original idea when moving to distributed architecture is that the default behavior should be the same as before. We discussed the option of keeping the original DSE in addition to the new DSE2, but ultimately decided we can switch completely over to DSE2 but use the in-memory transport to replicate the same behavior as the original DSE. With that thinking, it doesn't make sense for someone installing a single-process program to do any transport_url configuration (just as it wasn't needed before the distributed architecture). What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2017-11-22 08:49:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I understand Eric, I'm concerned that the komubu+memory option is only  testing purpose, so i doubt its stable enough to be added as default config option. Do you have idea, that the driver is stable and can be used in production environment?

And also, old DSE architecture is deprecated long back, is it really needed to add it congress, because still adding third party lib config option to congress default list, still doesn't sound like good idea to me (as we dont own it , any change there, will break congress)"}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-23 14:22:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah I see. I understand your concern about stability. I'm not totally sure either. The only documentation I could find is this: http://docs.celeryproject.org/projects/kombu/en/latest/userguide/connections.html
What do you think?

As far as thirdparty lib config being broken by thirdparty changes, it seems to be the same situation with any other thirdparty dependency right? Any change in behavior can break Congress. It's something that's expected, and handled the best we can in testing and packaging. So for me it's not a problem, especially because the config option is easy to override. What do you think?

If we do configure it by default though, we should add kombu to requirements.txt
https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/global-requirements.txt#L104"}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-28 19:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

As Anusha said, the kombu in memory transport is intended for unit testing. Makes sense to always set rabbitMQ transport url in congress devstack plugin.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2017-11-29 01:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1

Merging now to make sure everything is ready to go for Queens-2.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 06:42:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix failure in devstack single node deployment of congress

Devstack seems to fail on single node/single process congress
deployment, with error missing transport_url. This commit fixes
the same by enabling setting of transport_url for single node
deployment as well.

Change-Id: I739db21caa4ab7a445f1f667258de5f2803b63c4
Closes-Bug:#1732851
'}]
commit_message:
Fix failure in devstack single node deployment of congress

Devstack seems to fail on single node/single process congress
deployment, with error missing transport_url. This commit fixes
the same by enabling setting of transport_url for single node
deployment as well.

Change-Id: I739db21caa4ab7a445f1f667258de5f2803b63c4
Closes-Bug:#1732851

commit_message:
Remove hardcoded skydive container image

The names of the images are controlled via tripleo-common and shouldn't
be hardcoded in t-h-t.

Change-Id: Ib9eb62ddc329a36fbd066a9528f4b94a12d54068
Closes-Bug: #1730487

commit_message:

The /opt/stack variable was being used in a single

commit_message:
Remove BASE var from vxlan_networking.sh

The /opt/stack variable was being used in a single
place and that use can be easily substituted
by the tripleo_root variable, which is the place
were the repositories are being downloaded. If
for some reason tripleo_root directory does not
end up in /new then an error appears as it won't
find /opt/stack/new/devstack/functions-common.

Change-Id: Ibff5e51c0b7a06b9915e222712738d6ca93a366f

commit_message:
Add exclude list to not override user data

Add an exclude list of file which can possibly
contains user data.
When those files are modified by the user, we should
not erased those when we update the plan during the
upgrade

Change-Id: I4e53d8f95170c25b32a6d714a7620c2c9d2596f3
Closes-Bug: #1734108
(cherry picked from commit 3a9337bb60168fcd328a3f63ee704e8e4d5a05f6)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 6681, 'name': 'Brent Eagles', 'email': 'beagles@redhat.com', 'username': 'beagles'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-18 06:07:48.000000000', 'message': 'include nova::compute::pci in compute.pp

This commit Iccf86f42448d2e7e682728cb82808f91b6d8124e in
puppet-nova change the way we configure the pci whitlist.

It is now require to include the nova::compute::pci class
to apply the pci whitelist configration on the compute node.

Change-Id: Ie29dcd8a9ac10f61c623149670094fa8b108d50d
'}]
commit_message:
include nova::compute::pci in compute.pp

This commit Iccf86f42448d2e7e682728cb82808f91b6d8124e in
puppet-nova change the way we configure the pci whitlist.

It is now require to include the nova::compute::pci class
to apply the pci whitelist configration on the compute node.

Change-Id: Ie29dcd8a9ac10f61c623149670094fa8b108d50d

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-22 16:07:14.000000000', 'message': '[rally] Port input task to the new format.

The new task format was introduced recently. It unifies different
sections and tries to make the things a bit simpler.

Rally task consists of subtasks. Their amout should be at least one.
The subtask is a group of workloads. Soon, it will be possible to define
a single SLA for all workloads in a subtask and even more - use once
executed contexts for workloads(i.e. create temporary users, network not
for an each workload, but for a group of them).

The workload is a combination of different plugins to be executed for a
test. The most important are Scenario plugin (what will be executed in
each iteration), runner (how the load should be generated) and contexts
(what resources should be precreated before the workload).

One scenario with different runners/contexts can create different load.
To distinguish them the new section "description" of workload was
introduced. It allows to add a custom description for a workload which
will be dispayed in the report files. In case of missed "description"
section, the description of scenario will be taken.

Also, I need to mentione that "failure_rate: 0" SLA is a default now, so
there is no need to specify it.

Change-Id: If99e8c722d9ccb18b8b9d7e12214e76e483a2016

commit_message:
[rally] Port input task to the new format.

The new task format was introduced recently. It unifies different
sections and tries to make the things a bit simpler.

Rally task consists of subtasks. Their amount should be at least one.
The subtask is a group of workloads. Soon, it will be possible to define
a single SLA for all workloads in a subtask and even more - use once
executed contexts for workloads (i.e. create temporary users, network not
for each workload but for a group of them).

The workload is a combination of different plugins to be executed for a
test. The most important are Scenario plugin (what will be executed in
each iteration), runner (how the load should be generated) and contexts
(what resources should be precreated before the workload).

One scenario with different runners/contexts can create different load.
To distinguish them the new section "description" of workload was
introduced. It allows to add a custom description for a workload which
will be dispayed in the report files. In case of missing "description"
section, the description of scenario will be taken.

Also, I need to mention that "failure_rate: 0" SLA is a default now, so
there is no need to specify it.

Change-Id: If99e8c722d9ccb18b8b9d7e12214e76e483a2016

subject: Add fallback to -eol tag if stable branch doesn't exists

commit_message:
Add fallback to -eol tag if stable branch doesn't exists

In order to support continued testing against EOL version of projects,
the setup_project function needs to be able to understand checking out
to an eol tag.

Change-Id: I1b2d030df8cb2a850bf9248595171d96a813d381

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 17:43:04.000000000', 'message': 'Use new oslo.context arg names

Various RequestContext values have been renamed and the old names
deprecated. This results in a large amount of DeprecationWarning
messages in the logs.

commit_message:
Use new oslo.context arg names

Various RequestContext values have been renamed and the old names
deprecated. This results in a large amount of DeprecationWarning
messages in the logs.

This updates glance.context.RequestContext to use the new names.

Change-Id: Id34637542051cfdc532eebdfbf95edd8a58467da

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Releasenotes are version independent, so remove version/release display.
This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html

Change-Id: Iaa7b81302a8d53da7dad0101f8732a0fb64f4616

commit_message:
Align default policy in code with the one in conf

Our policy.json default value was changed from everybody to
"role:admin". this change will align the code with the
default config file provided for clarity and consistency.

Change-Id: I60228949c0288ef5f3ce71c427e4d62781cdd56b

commit_message:
Use new oslo.db base test case

Base migration test cases have moved to a new location in oslo.db
resulting in DeprecationWarnings in the logs. This updates the
migration tests to use the new location for these base classes.

Change-Id: I25e41fc4103b4eafd3aef2b0a863b2053927edad

Spec: Developer Environment

environment.

subject: Enable os-collect-config service
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-27 23:14:54.000000000', 'message': 'Enable os-collect-config service

When using get-occ-config.sh to configure pre-provisioned nodes, the
os-collect-config service may not have been enabled by default. This can
lead to reboots causing future updates or upgrade processes to fail.

Change-Id: If7d4dbcc721fbb0ea835dbd70126f9532a94d937
Closes-Bug: #1734783
'}]
commit_message:
Enable os-collect-config service

When using get-occ-config.sh to configure pre-provisioned nodes, the
os-collect-config service may not have been enabled by default. This can
lead to reboots causing future updates or upgrade processes to fail.

Change-Id: If7d4dbcc721fbb0ea835dbd70126f9532a94d937
Closes-Bug: #1734783

commit_message:
Remove ceilometerclient from requirements.txt

The Ceilometer datasource driver was removed in [1], and now that
python-ceilometerclient has been officially removed [2] we should
remove it from the requirements, too.

[1] - https://review.openstack.org/517527
[2] - https://review.openstack.org/522183

Change-Id: If8ec7ff00d0242c96fafaa466b63d976eca1269c

commit_message:
ci: add ovb-ha.yaml

Add an environment that deploys a basic overcloud:

- Pacemaker to test HA on 3 controllers
- Keystone, Glance, Nova, Neutron, Swift

Also change the zuul layout to run ovb-ha scenario when
touching ovb-ha.yaml file.

Change-Id: I865901f38250a13d8ea914a54072d6eb584a050d

[{'created': '2017-11-22 23:16:59.000000000', 'message': "Swap the order of stdout and stderr in debug output

Generally this data is looked at because something failed, and in
that case the relevant error is likely to be at the end of stderr.
By concatenating the output stderr first and then stdout as we were
it is possible for the stderr to get lost entirely in the failures

Change-Id: I952fd1af5778ade1eb6b0599d983f98cadeb7f6f

Change-Id: I952fd1af5778ade1eb6b0599d983f98cadeb7f6f

commit_message:
Swap the order of stdout and stderr in debug output

Generally this data is looked at because something failed, and in
that case the relevant error is likely to be at the end of stderr.
By concatenating the output stderr first and then stdout as we were
it is possible for the stderr to get lost entirely in the failures
list, and even if that doesn't happen it's best to output the
relevant error right at the end of the output where people will
see it.  Previously it would be buried in the middle of the debug
output.

Change-Id: I952fd1af5778ade1eb6b0599d983f98cadeb7f6f

commit_message:
[nova] start VMs by default on pod/node restart

If a node or pod restarts we would like the VMs running state to be
preserved.

Change-Id: I025b4e806855102c90711b6644a7f32bb20602b9

[{'created': '2017-08-14 13:03:13.000000000', 'message': 'Remove initScope from trunk delete.action.service

The initScope method is deprecated, the preferred way of initializing
action services is the use of initAction.

Change-Id: I689a98697d997780af42eb31a4b5eeee2ddf9b0f
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui
'}, {'created': '2017-08-17 14:18:58.000000000', 'message': "Remove initScope from trunk delete.action.service

The initScope method is deprecated, the action service should be
stateless.

Also refactor to simplify delete action logic. Some code got carried
over from the images panel, what we originally used as an example. But
much of that code was doing checks useless for trunks. Trunks don't have
complicated 'public' and 'shared' attributes controlling who can operate
on them. A simple policy check will suffice.

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I689a98697d997780af42eb31a4b5eeee2ddf9b0f
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui
Related-Bug: #1640049

commit_message:
Remove initScope from trunk delete.action.service

The initScope method is deprecated, the action service should be
stateless.

Also refactor to simplify delete action logic. Some code got carried
over from the images panel, what we originally used as an example. But
much of that code was doing checks useless for trunks. Trunks don't have
complicated 'public' and 'shared' attributes controlling who can operate
on them. A simple policy check will suffice.

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I689a98697d997780af42eb31a4b5eeee2ddf9b0f
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui
Related-Bug: #1640049

subject: include compute::pci in compute.pp
messages:
[{'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2017-11-15 10:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2017-11-15 10:33:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2017-11-15 15:43:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2017-11-15 16:55:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)

yes the pci alias should be configure on the controller and compute.
This is because nova change to fix the cold migration for pci passthrough. before the fix pci alisa was configure only on the controller. this is the related nova fix https://review.openstack.org/#/c/307124/.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2017-11-15 20:00:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > yes the pci alias should be configure on the controller and
 > compute.
 > This is because nova change to fix the cold migration for pci
 > passthrough. before the fix pci alisa was configure only on the
 > controller. this is the related nova fix https://review.openstack.org/#/c/307124/.

Sorry I didn't word this very well. I was referring to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/476327/ and that it didn't seem necessary to move the pci whitelist configuration out of compute.pp only to necessitate the include. Sorry for the confusion."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-11-16 17:15:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

In this case I'm not sure this is necessary because you can just include the nova::compute::pci in the calling manifest. For example, https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/compute.pp#L49.  The danger of including this here is that anyone who has configured this in their manifest this may introduce compile failures.  Please add a release note warning of such things as this would be an upgrade impact if defining it in the calling manifest is not sufficient"}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2017-11-18 06:09:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> In this case I'm not sure this is necessary because you can just
 > include the nova::compute::pci in the calling manifest. For
 > example, https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/compute.pp#L49.
 >  The danger of including this here is that anyone who has
 > configured this in their manifest this may introduce compile
 > failures.  Please add a release note warning of such things as this
 > would be an upgrade impact if defining it in the calling manifest
 > is not sufficient

So is this approach better https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521232/ ? I tested and both of them are working"}, {'account_id': 12171, 'date': '2017-11-28 23:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

will do different approach in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521232/'}]

[{'created': '2017-11-15 10:28:20.000000000', 'message': 'include compute::pci in compute.pp

To allow configure the pci whitelist in nova compute
we need to include the nova::compute:pci.

Change-Id: I873b19697e32598ee2bf93e2736eb98bfdd212b9
'}]
commit_message:
include compute::pci in compute.pp

To allow configure the pci whitelist in nova compute
we need to include the nova::compute:pci.

Change-Id: I873b19697e32598ee2bf93e2736eb98bfdd212b9

It also does a better job of gathering failure details from the clients.

See https://github.com/kgiusti/ombt

Be aware I haven't had a chance to test this at any real scale, and the code's been refactored quite heavily so no doubt there's bugs lurking in there. revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 17:17:07.000000000', 'message': 'Fix provisioned_capacity_gb for drivers that don't report it

A backend may advertise "thin_provisioning_support" to the
Cinder scheduler, but may not have an efficient way to calculate
the "provisioned_capacity_gb" on that backend. The assumption
in Cinder has been that we will fall back on the
allocated_capacity_gb for such backends.

Change-Id: I72175890d67804b19883c1e6503833dd10806cf5
Related-Bug: #1714209
'}]
commit_message:
Fix provisioned_capacity_gb for drivers that don't report it

A backend may advertise "thin_provisioning_support" to the
Cinder scheduler, but may not have an efficient way to calculate
the "provisioned_capacity_gb" on that backend. The assumption
in Cinder has been that we will fall back on the
allocated_capacity_gb for such backends.

Change-Id: I72175890d67804b19883c1e6503833dd10806cf5
Related-Bug: #1714209

commit_message:
Download Kubespray instead of git clone

We don't install git by default (at least in CI), so let's use a
tarball instead of git clone to get Kubespray sources.

Change-Id: I8321206b095effbc482779a10ff77fd18299bbdf
Depends-On: I2da025961c584cb1adc83943561b1d9faa3559b1

commit_message:
Fix admin/project instance UT

The expected error count was wrongly changed in
commit df194c8b4c25c6128f03a98fd0e628ba14b743ff.

The expected error count was changed from 1 to 2 in the commit
but one new error message was caused by a wrong test code.
api.glance.image_list_detailed should return a tuple of
(images, has_more, has_prev) but the mocked method only returns
a list of images and this causes another error.

Change-Id: Ic1083014f9572bfd20adc60e7ec3eeeac387e9d5

(6 comments)

I would really like to get some feedback from downstream (other than Red Hat <wink>) and deployment specialists (like OSA and others) about the approach described in the BP.

This will also break everyone if it’s merged. We need to be really mindful of that :-)

Having the configuration defaults in “utils” smells bad to me - I would prefer to see them in a “config” directory please to make it clearer they’re actual configuration settings and not just utilities for configuration. Hilariously though we’d then have a “conf” and “config” directory (though why the former isn’t called “policies” is another question).

There’s a few variables in settings.py that aren’t moved to .conf - any reason why? There also seems to be a lot of local_settings.py missing from the new conf setup - was that all going to be migrated?'}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-03 14:40:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 34:

(3 comments)

The way this works, the old settings in local_settings.py continue to work as before -- I'm only adding a new source of settings. That means that we won't break existing installations horribly -- it's all backwards compatible. We can remove the support for the python-based configuration at some point in the future, though, and we will probably want to do that.

Not all settings have been moved out of local_settings.py and into local_settings.conf, because this patch only deals with Django-specific configuration. Moving all the settings at once was what I tried last time, and it was impossible to merge it, because of all the conflicts with all the other patches. This time I want to do it piecemeal, starting with the Django configuration because it's the hardest, and then continuing with other areas.

I agree that this directory is not the best place for this code. I will think of something better."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-03 16:05:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 35.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-03 16:38:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35: Verified+1

(4 comments)

Overall, moving to ini is definitely a win for operators. However, shoving Python syntax into ini when operators will be unfamiliar with it in that context is a recipe for disaster. I'd strongly urge you to reconsider your design on this."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 17:27:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 17:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

Moving the configuration format to ini is already a big task, unlikely to be merged any time soon.

Moving to ini while at the same changing all the settings is never going to succeed on a project this size.'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:09:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

> Moving to ini while at the same [time] changing all the settings is never going to succeed on a project this size.

So changing all the settings would imply changing defaults to. Changing the *structure* of the settings is already being done. You're just choosing to not think too long about how to best keep that structure consistent throughout the file.

At the moment you seem to have bled two different sets of potential users of these configuration files:

- People who want to configure Django
- People who want to configure the OpenStack Dashboard

In the former category, you're doing a *LOT* of work for nothing. People who want to configure Django are already familiar and comfortable with local_settings.py. If that's who you're trying to satisfy, then I'm a *very* strong -1 because this work is extra and unnecessary for them.

In the latter category, I suspect they've been using the documentation to get by (unless they also know Django and Python). They would benefit from a configuration file that is 100% ini as they expect to see it for the rest of OpenStack.

Certainly, some of the *example* names I chose to illustrate how those items *should* be converted to ini might not be optimal. I'm not saying you have to use those or scrap the whole business, but you can't say that this will satisfy both groups of people or that this is targetted to operators wanting to configure Django. That makes absolutely no sense. If anyone's going to benefit from this change it's the common OpenStack operator. And if that's who you are actually developing this for, then you *should* convert thet entire thing. And you *should* write detailed documentation explaining how to migrate. If you do convert the entire thing to regular ini (not this blended approach) then writing a tool to convert existing local_settings.py for operators to the ini files would be incredibly easy.

I understand that it's easy to get attached to clever code that's already written, but I think this approach is actively harmful at the moment."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:41:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

Let's work on a better structure then firs, *as a separate patch*, and do the transition to ini files once that is done then.

I understand now that the examples your gave of the new structure you are proposing were not very well thought out and don't  give justice to how this would look like in practice. That makes it very hard to judge the proposed structure against what I'm proposing right now.

Do you think you could provide a more complete example? For example, could you take the local_settings.py.example file, and convert it whole into the format you are advocating, so that we can see what you are exactly proposing and how well it would work in practice with the settings we have?"}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:46:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:53:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

Radomir Dopieralski wrote:

> Let's work on a better structure then firs, *as a separate patch*,
> and do the transition to ini files once that is done then.

Sure! Smaller, easier to review patches are my preference anyway =)

> I understand now that the examples your gave of the new structure
> you are proposing were not very well thought out and don't  give
> justice to how this would look like in practice. That makes it very
> hard to judge the proposed structure against what I'm proposing
> right now.
>
> Do you think you could provide a more complete example? For example,
> could you take the local_settings.py.example file, and convert it
> whole into the format you are advocating, so that we can see what
> you are exactly proposing and how well it would work in practice
> with the settings we have?

So really, all I'm objecting to is how you've chosen to translate items (like caches, and the websso nested lists) into INI. Everything else you have looks perfectly fine to me. Those more complex python structures can be represented differently in a way that looks and is INI.

In short, the pattern in other projects, is to use references to other sections that then form the structure that you're looking for. What's necessary is finding good, descriptive, ini section names for them. Let me take a shot at converting the local_settings.py.example file though and get back to you. I might have better suggestions for naming after that."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-17 18:59:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

Believe me, I tried what you describe, and I couldn't make it work reasonably well. I'm all for it if it can be done cleanly, but I failed at that. It doesn't help that oslo.config doesn't really let you handle dynamic section names, and that I had to hack that on top of it..."}, {'account_id': 12000, 'date': '2017-01-17 19:20:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

So I put a bit more thought into this: https://gist.github.com/sigmavirus24/2c222c6bd69104856a64dd2a5de735e1

There's also some consolidation that can happen based on what I see. Having sections mapped to services (identity, image, etc.) allows for some compression of configuration. Let me know if those examples aren't thorough enough."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-01-18 10:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

Thank you. I have put your example on Gerrit so that we can comment on it easier: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/421779'}, {'account_id': 12071, 'date': '2017-01-19 01:52:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37: Code-Review-2

I applied the suggested changes, and I got this to work with oslo-config-generator, at least provisionally. There is still a huge problem with handling Django's lazily translated strings -- I am not sure if oslo-config has a way of forcing a casting to a string for it before printing it.

I was also thinking about dropping the config groups entirely, at least initially, and going for a completely flat settings file, just like the local_settings.py file is right now. This would have two advantages: first, we don't need to change the documentation to reflect the changed option names and to which group an option belongs, second, we sidestep the discussions about which option should go to which group."}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2017-05-02 15:25:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

And of course the help strings need to be filled for all the options, but I imagine that would be a separate commit.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-05-02 15:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 40: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-30 11:54:08.000000000', 'message': "Move all Django configuration into .conf file

All Django-related configuration options have been moved into
the local_settings.conf file. All the post-processing logic is
still there in settings.py.

Note, that those options will still work if specified in
local_settings.py or local_settings.d -- I'm basically adding
one more source of configuration. We can remove the original
config files once we migrate everything.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bp/ini-based-settings
Change-Id: I2ed79ef0c6ac6d3816bba13346b7d001c46a7e80

Note, that those options will still work if specified in
local_settings.py or local_settings.d -- I'm basically adding
one more source of configuration. We can remove the original
config files once we migrate everything.

commit_message:
Use oslo.config for Horizon configuration

This patch adds the infrastructure needed to move the configuration
of Horizon into oslo.config-compatible configuration file, instead of
the Django's Python-based configuration. It doesn't actually define
any configuration options, just the mechanism for loading them and the
additional types necessary to handle Horizon's complex configuration,
and the integration with oslo-config-generator.

Subsequent patches will add groups of options, making it possible to use
them in the local_settings.conf file instead of the local_settings.py
file. Note, that the options specified in the local_settings.py file
will continue to work.

Partially-Implements: blueprint ini-based-configuration
Change-Id: I2ed79ef0c6ac6d3816bba13346b7d001c46a7e80

commit_message:
tripleo-buildimage: deploy repo in pre-run

OpenStack Infra removed the centos-release-openstack-ocata rpm from
nodepool-centos7 image, so tripleo build images job started to fail
because we need qemu-img-ev in bindep (provided by RDO repo).

So this patch brings back the package prior to run the actual tests.

Change-Id: Ie760e2b61dd76cb680dd2f4e553d3fb6c9b889aa

Is this WIP waiting for tests as per todo? if so please -workflow (and possibly add WIP to commit message) to make it clear to reviewers :)'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-09-15 15:53:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

> Is this WIP waiting for tests as per todo? if so please -workflow
 > (and possibly add WIP to commit message) to make it clear to
 > reviewers :)

Despite having a TODO in the commit message and -1 from Jenkins (both because of tests missing) we would welcome reviews about this change as it is. The functional part of it is a practically complete feature.

Basically we'd like to proceed like this:

 1) hoping to get some high-level feedback until we get the basic direction okay
 2) then we'll write the missing tests of course (but this way we don't have to possibly re-write the tests multiple times)
 3) then the whole can be reviewed together with the tests until it's ready to merge

We discussed this shortly on one of the Denver PTG sessions and folks seemed to be okay with it."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-22 14:22:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review-1

'}, {'created': '2017-08-09 14:49:30.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Trunks panel: edit button

TODO tests

Trunk edit is a 2-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector step reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I4a9f3bd710c9f6bc9ed942b107c6720865b1bc73
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

In the port selector step reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I4a9f3bd710c9f6bc9ed942b107c6720865b1bc73
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui
'}]
commit_message:
Trunks panel: edit button

Trunk edit is a 2-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector step reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

Co-Authored-By: Bence Romsics <bence.romsics@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I4a9f3bd710c9f6bc9ed942b107c6720865b1bc73
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

As discussed with Rob on IRC in angular-schema-form there's no support for a table select widget, so that way we can't make the (parent and sub-) port allocation user friendly. Therefore in patch set #2 I switched to the older wizard modal. In the hope of becoming able to reuse the port allocation tool from launch instance. See also the ORC logs:

(3 comments)

I tested the patch in my local environment.

It works well in very normal scenarios. Thanks.

I also see several points to be improved.

- (1) In the available port lists in Parent Port or Subports menu, I see ports used by another trunk (as parent port or subport) in the list. Is it an expected behavior?

- (2) When I tried to create a trunk by specifying a neutron port which is already used as a parent port by another trunk, an error message was shown, but the error message was shown in the background and the "Create Trunk" form continued to be shown in the foreground. I think it is a confusing behavior. At first I met this situation, I clicked "Create" button several times and finally I noticed several number of error messages were shown in the background (gray area). Combining with (1), I think there are several cases where error messages are returned, so it looks better to address at least (1) or (2).

- (3) After I opened "Create Trunk" form, I created a new port named "parent1" from CLI. Then I closed the form by clicking "Cancel" and re-clicked "Create Trunk" button. In the opened form, I expected to see the created port "parent1" in the port list in the parent port, but I did not see the port newly created. (I just forgot to prepare a parent port before opening the "Create Trunk" form and created a port from CLI. I don't think I did some special thing.) The only solution I found is to click "Trunks" in the left side menu. It seems the code for "Create Trunk" form reloads the port data only when clicking the panel is reloaded. I think this is surprising behavior for users.

- (4) It would be nice if we can create a port from the "Create Trunk" form. At now, we need to prepare a port in the other form "Create Port" in horizon or create a port from CLI. When we create a port from CLI, we will hit the situation described at (3).'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-07-20 10:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-07-20 10:27:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)

Welcome back Akihiro! Thanks for the review. And sorry for the huge patch size.

 > - (1) In the available port lists in Parent Port or Subports menu,
 > I see ports used by another trunk (as parent port or subport) in
 > the list. Is it an expected behavior?

Not expected in the end. We have multiple places where port filtering is
required based on port subtype (regular / trunk parent / subport):

* launch instance port selector: should show regulars and parents
* trunk parent selector: should show regulars
* trunk subport selector: should show regulars

We'd like to keep the filtering (or subtype) logic at one place
and use the same from all three. We have a change for the logic:
Ie3a6710eeffefcb472c569898d0f1f1554e599f7 However that change already
went through several review rounds and I don't know how it will look
in the end. Therefore I'd like to integrate that here only after it
was finalized.

Until the integration of that change the help also documents that the
same port should not be used twice.

 > - (2) When I tried to create a trunk by specifying a neutron port
 > which is already used as a parent port by another trunk, an error
 > message was shown, but the error message was shown in the
 > background and the "Create Trunk" form continued to be shown in the
 > foreground. I think it is a confusing behavior. At first I met this
 > situation, I clicked "Create" button several times and finally I
 > noticed several number of error messages were shown in the
 > background (gray area). Combining with (1), I think there are
 > several cases where error messages are returned, so it looks better
 > to address at least (1) or (2).

This problem goes away when (1) is solved.

(However I see different behavior. Strange. Besides the toast in the
background, I also have the error message from neutron's response
displayed in the foreground  - on the top of the create modal. That
error message is visible and informative. I don't know the reason for
this difference.)

 > - (3) After I opened "Create Trunk" form, I created a new port
 > named "parent1" from CLI. Then I closed the form by clicking
 > "Cancel" and re-clicked "Create Trunk" button. In the opened form,
 > I expected to see the created port "parent1" in the port list in
 > the parent port, but I did not see the port newly created. (I just
 > forgot to prepare a parent port before opening the "Create Trunk"
 > form and created a port from CLI. I don't think I did some special
 > thing.) The only solution I found is to click "Trunks" in the left
 > side menu. It seems the code for "Create Trunk" form reloads the
 > port data only when clicking the panel is reloaded. I think this is
 > surprising behavior for users.

We are aware of this problem, please see here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468396/16/openstack_dashboard/static/app/core/trunks/actions/create.action.service.js@104

I agree this is surprising and port data should be loaded only when
'create trunk' was clicked.

However when I tried to do that (in perform() of create.action.service)
then we hit a synchronization issue.  The getPorts and getNetworks
promises completed later than transfertable initialization, therefore
no available ports were displayed.

We are a bit stuck on this. We would appreciate any help on how to solve
the synchronization problem and initialize transfertable only after the
ports were loaded. Or re-initialize it.
 
 > - (4) It would be nice if we can create a port from the "Create
 > Trunk" form. At now, we need to prepare a port in the other form
 > "Create Port" in horizon or create a port from CLI. When we create
 > a port from CLI, we will hit the situation described at (3).

While being user friendly this would have serious UI side effects
and maintenance costs I believe. We discussed something similar with
Rob on the Atlanta PTG. IIRC his preference was to avoid duplicating
logic that's already available in other panels. For example by the same
reasoning we could add port creation to launch instance too. But if we
followed through on the idea, the user interface would explode (trunk
needs port, port needs network, port needs subnet, and so on). So I
think this behavior would not be in line with other parts of horizon.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-07-20 11:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Verified+1

I tested this patch. Feedbacks are as follows:

- It is better to show device_owner/device ID in the available table. In the port table of the network detail page, we can see "Attached Device". When creating/updating a trunk, we need to create ports in advance, so I would like to check which ports are in use and which are not used. "Attached Device" information is important to me.
- When I open trunk create form when I logged in as admin user, I see ports from other projects. The project panel focuses on project operation regardless of admin role, so I believe we expect only ports from a current project are shown in the form.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-10-26 10:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 33: Patch Set 32 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-10-26 11:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 34: Patch Set 33 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-10-27 13:25:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 35.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-10-27 13:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35:

> - It is better to show device_owner/device ID in the available
 > table. In the port table of the network detail page, we can see
 > "Attached Device". When creating/updating a trunk, we need to
 > create ports in advance, so I would like to check which ports are
 > in use and which are not used. "Attached Device" information is
 > important to me.

I added the device_id to the parent port selector step.

I did not add device_id to the subport selector step or device_owner anywhere because the ports are pre-filtered based on device_owner already by isParentPortCandidate() and isSubportCandidate(). See here:

openstack_dashboard/static/app/core/trunks/actions/ports-extra.service.js

So even if we did show device_id for subports for example, it would be always empty.

 > - When I open trunk create form when I logged in as admin user, I
 > see ports from other projects. The project panel focuses on project
 > operation regardless of admin role, so I believe we expect only
 > ports from a current project are shown in the form.

Fixed. Thanks for finding this. Soon we'll upload a new patch adding the admin trunks panel too.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-27 15:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35:

> I did not add device_id to the subport selector step or device_owner anywhere because the ports are pre-filtered based on device_owner already by isParentPortCandidate() and isSubportCandidate(). See here:
> openstack_dashboard/static/app/core/trunks/actions/ports-extra.service.js
> So even if we did show device_id for subports for example, it would be always empty.

When I tested I had a number of unattached ports (more than 10 such ports) from more than five networks) , so I might be confused. Let me try it with the latest patch again.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2017-10-31 07:53:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35: Code-Review-1

> > I did not add device_id to the subport selector step or device_owner anywhere because the ports are pre-filtered based on device_owner already by isParentPortCandidate() and isSubportCandidate(). See here:
> > openstack_dashboard/static/app/core/trunks/actions/ports-extra.service.js
> > So even if we did show device_id for subports for example, it would be always empty.

> When I tested I had a number of unattached ports (more than 10 such ports) from more than five networks) , so I might be confused. Let me try it with the latest patch again.

I confirmed it works as expected. Ports with device_id/device_owner are not shown in subports choices.
Perhaps I was confused with parent ports choices.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-31 14:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

Btw, is there any reason you don't show device owner in the port choices for parent port and sub ports? Device ID is shown, so Device Owner is useful to me too."}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2017-11-01 19:47:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 37:

> Btw, is there any reason you don't show device owner in the port
 > choices for parent port and sub ports? Device ID is shown, so
 > Device Owner is useful to me too.

I will add it in the next patch set. Originally I didn't because of the port filtering it carries very little information. If device_id is there the owner must be 'compute:*'. Otherwise it must be empty."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-11-11 08:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37:

'}, {'created': '2017-07-18 13:18:46.000000000', 'message': "Trunks panel: create button

Reused and built on port allocator transfertable from launch instance.

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

To test it devstack needs to have neutron with trunk support, eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

No special horizon config is needed. As long as the 'trunk'
API extension is available (openstack extension show trunk)
the panel should automatically appear under Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

TODO unit tests: better coverage

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of

"}, {'created': '2017-08-09 14:49:30.000000000', 'message': "WIP Trunks panel: create button

TODO #1 tackle the deprecated use of initScope in actions
        cf. https://review.openstack.org/345145
TODO #2 get rid of the inconsistencies of crossHide
        maybe solving #1 first will help
TODO #3 adapt tests to changes in the last few patch sets

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

"}, {'created': '2017-08-30 13:05:19.000000000', 'message': "Trunks panel: create button

TODO adapt tests to changes in the last few patch sets

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

commit_message:
Trunks panel: create button

Trunk creation is a 3-step workflow:
  * Basic trunk attributes
  * Parent port selector transfertable:
      Selects a single port (mandatory)
  * Subports selector transfertable:
      Selects many ports with segmentation details (optional)

In the port selector steps reused and built on port allocator
transfertable from launch instance.

The easiest way to test is to take the whole change series by taking the
last change in it, then build devstack with neutron trunk support. Eg:

  local.conf:
  enable_plugin neutron https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  enable_service q-trunk

If you want to test this change in isolation you also need the following
Horizon config:

  openstack_dashboard/enabled/_1500_project_trunks_panel.py:
  DISABLED = False  # or just remove this line

As long as the 'trunk' API extension is available (openstack
extension show trunk) the panel should automatically appear under
Project/Network/Trunks.

To try the 'inherit' segmentation type the subports must be ports of
vlan type provider networks.

Co-Authored-By: Lajos Katona <lajos.katona@ericsson.com>
Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>
Change-Id: I663a7e0158335155fe11f0fc40d9fa86bf984ae0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-trunk-ui

commit_message:
Remove agent/dhcp_agent_scheduler extensions

networking-ovn doesn't actually support these extensions, so
remove them.

Change-Id: Ic9ef37a80116bb0166d3638ad2789a995480e7db
(cherry picked from commit 8f0942cbed9e55f071d297d34dfbc8784b448ba5)

commit_message:
Only monitor the necessary SB tables for changes

There is no reason to waste memory storing tables in the
Southbound DB that we don't use.

Change-Id: Iba03bbd735f61c16dcc22b5d11d030bd18549b5b
(cherry picked from commit 0e34fbab5edb9999c48b44c3efa8b08b61216127)

messages:
[{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2017-11-13 15:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-11-13 22:09:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-11-13 22:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

actually, we may want to use %r here, since it will give more data https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6005159/when-to-use-r-instead-of-s-in-python'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2017-11-14 00:19:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> actually, we may want to use %r here, since it will give more data
 > https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6005159/when-to-use-r-instead-of-s-in-python

As pointed out by reviewer in another patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510308/), this variable is the name of an entry point which is a string so I think using %r won't give more data in here."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2017-11-14 05:59:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

> > actually, we may want to use %r here, since it will give more

 > 
 > As pointed out by reviewer in another patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510308/),
 > this variable is the name of an entry point which is a string so I
 > think using %r won't give more data in here.

thanks for the explanation!"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2017-11-23 00:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-11-28 20:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 12:31:05.000000000', 'message': '[placement] Fix GET PUT /allocations nits

In the review of I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc, a few
non-blocking nits were identified. This change addresses some of
those nits, fixing some typos, clarifying method names and what
microversion is in use at particular times.

'}]
commit_message:
[placement] Fix GET PUT /allocations nits

In the review of I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc, a few
non-blocking nits were identified. This change addresses some of
those nits, fixing some typos, clarifying method names and what
microversion is in use at particular times.

Change-Id: Iff15340502ce43eba3b98db26aa0652b1da24504

messages:
[{'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-20 11:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-11-20 12:02:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm not sure whether we want this in general, it might produce a lot of noise.

But if we add it, let's fix the comment first."}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-20 12:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I ran this here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/520055/

As you can see in worst case it takes 150K, usually less - 100-120K.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-20 12:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-20 12:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2017-11-20 12:20:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-11-20 14:14:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-11-20 19:10:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Let's not do this on all nodes and jobs by default, please do it on a job basis if it's particularly troublesome for a job.

In the meantime, this made me realize that DNS lookups are indeed failing on a fairly regular basis. I'll investigate to see if I can find a root cause."}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2017-11-20 19:37:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I don't mind if we try it, especially when it comes to intermittent DNS failures. If, it does expose a specific failure or configuration error, we can then see about reverting if needed"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-11-21 10:13:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

there is really nothing one could do worse when it comes for DNS issues troubleshooting. It's all for goodness :D"}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-11-28 20:19:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-28 21:26:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Set unbound logging to debug

Set unbound logging to debug for easy investigation of
DNS queries failures.

Change-Id: I4aea0f596479d97f64ec12039a0c350e25457d87

'}, {'created': '2017-10-24 10:20:23.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to lib/neutron

Plan is to move to devstack/lib/neutron, but networking-odl uses
devstack/lib/neutron-legacy. This patch switch networking-odl from
lib/neutron-legacy to lib/neutron. There are some changes in the
lib/neutron, now services names are going to be neutron-api,
neutron-dhcp, neutron-metadata-agent etc instead of q-svc, q-dhcp
and q-meta.

Change-Id: Id9365d022eef030685eea752b5dabff655931bdb
'}, {'created': '2017-10-31 03:47:11.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to lib/neutron

commit_message:
Switch to lib/neutron

Plan is to move to devstack/lib/neutron, but networking-odl uses
devstack/lib/neutron-legacy. This patch switch networking-odl from
lib/neutron-legacy to lib/neutron. There are some changes in the
lib/neutron, now services names are going to be neutron-api,
neutron-dhcp, neutron-metadata-agent etc instead of q-svc, q-dhcp
and q-meta.

Change-Id: Id9365d022eef030685eea752b5dabff655931bdb

- gate-keystone-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/44/460344/2/check/gate-keystone-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial/6071b89//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 51s

(10 comments)

I really like getting this written down. Thank you!!

I think we are missing a lot of the *why* here that is so important to understanding the use cases. I added a few things I think we should add here.

I think when you add an API user delegating access, a whole bunch of extra user cases start cropping up, so I feel they should really be considered separately here. I am not saying its not useful, but its lots of complexity from a use case point of view.

I see two big stages here:

* Basic operator driven RBAC
* Delegation of RBAC to tenant admins that set cloud defined course grained roles to users in their tree of tenants (similar to hierarchical quotas)
* Fine grained delegation by end users, to allow scripts and services to work with least privilege

The more I think about this, the more I think linux has an interesting way of keeping it simple, using fine grained groups (we could say... projects) to split up the world. Thats why I lean towards giving scripts full access to their own dedicated sub-project, and dealing with the sharing with sub-projects instead, so the delegation piece is really sharing a resource explicitly with the created sub-project., and you can restrict most people to only share a projects resource with things in its own sub-project tree, etc. Now thats a heap of work, but it feels simpler to me.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-04-27 13:58:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-04-27 13:58:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Policy is three things today.
1. RBAC
2. Scope check
3. Custom (Neutron etc)

Keystone should only care about RBAC.

Thus, one goal should be to split RBAC from scope check, perform scope check in code, and RBAC in Middelware.

This document should be explicitly focused on RBAC.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2017-05-01 17:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

suggests some cross-project process and tools we can use to help
make progress towards better policy in OpenStack.

commit_message:
Outline policy goals

This document is intended to document the goals we need from a policy
implementation. In addition to that, this document also suggests some
cross-project tools we can use to help make progress towards better
policy in OpenStack.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Young <ayoung@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt <john@johngarbutt.com>

Change-Id: I57b2b38db8d5d9368a1056363a87788572712338

commit_message:
Remove httpd log dir for glance-api

Glance API still runs eventlet, the
/var/log/containers/httpd/glance-api directory on the host serves no
purpose and confuses users. Remove it.

Change-Id: Idcd26571d20f02b723af9938ba625c9fa548c0d7
Closes-Bug: #1728562

commit_message:
Release python-brick-cinderclient-ext 0.6.0

The currently python-brick-cinderclient-ext does not
work with the latest release of os-brick (2.1.0).
This release includes a fix to remove deprecated
constants and move to using the appropriate
constants.

There is an update to dependencies included so doing
this a feature release bumping 0.5.0 to 0.6.0.

Change-Id: Ibbc803fc053d030ab88e95d578ce07125c191972

commit_message:
Remove zone_id on import compare

If the import is fast, it can be done by the show, so we can't compare
zone_id.

Closes-Bug: #1734868

Change-Id: I291155304a36142ec2fd2f772215bb10f2dbae11

commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

Also, use openstackdocstheme for releasenotes.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I1357eda2330c095bdc1e3a3697faabfbca4b6a8e

Remove a redundant self argument in decorators

The wrapper function takes *func_args and **kwargs,
therefore, "self" argument is redundant.

Change-Id: Ibbe7acfe4cb91d4f1b26d96dbc5088a4720a2b56

commit_message:
Fix for timeouts on scale down

There were two issues: The action timeout and the wait_for_messages
timeout.

The wait_for_messages did not need a timeout here and it was causing the
bug. I added an cli option for the timeout and setup a reasonable
default (the previous default was over 4 hours that would invalidate
keystone session duration)

Change-Id: I232d071516d3f53f9f87143d9d65ebe3e58b0f38
Closes-Bug: 1734712

commit_message:
Add exclude list to not override user data

Add an exclude list of file which can possibly
contains user data.
When those files are modified by the user, we should
not erased those when we update the plan during the
upgrade

Change-Id: I4e53d8f95170c25b32a6d714a7620c2c9d2596f3
Closes-Bug: #1734108

commit_message:
link to the mitaka CLI guide

Replace the use of the project_guides.tmpl template in the mitaka
index file with inline versions that link to the mitaka-specific
pages.

Add a language-bindings.html page based on the one for ocata to link
to the user-guide and cli-reference for mitaka.

Add a projects.html page to link to the mitaka documentation for each
service project.

Change-Id: I173ecabeb3aa74a3d2ddc6b4ba898d881dcf752d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
link to mitaka versions of admin and user guides

As part of the documentation retention policy change, we recovered the
user, admin, and CLI guides for Mitaka. This patch links to the first
two. Linking to the CLI guide will come later in this patch series.

Change-Id: I3b6981ad01fb00944f65cdd13682c9ca531393c2
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
libvirt: remove extraneous retry assignment in cleanup method

The retry = False assignments in these blocks was pointless
because we raise an exception out of them anyway, so the retry
variable isn't going to be read again.

Change-Id: Ie52044ed9ad8520e3878de60365cdea22596aa78

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-27 14:34:00.000000000', 'message': "Fix data send in notification after QoS policy update

During update of QoS policy object when e.g. policy's name
is changed rules belongs to policy wasn't send properly in
notification.
This patch fixes this issue by getting existing qos policy object
instead of creating new one for update.

This issue is already fixed in Pike branch with patch:
I57011bd4d40479855203061554090d19bb668960

Change-Id: I6f5a925084bb70b56e66d673eac2febdb38e0b34
Related-Bug: #1734136
"}, {'created': '2017-11-27 20:24:14.000000000', 'message': "Don't create new QoS policy during update operation

The QoS plugin erroneously creates a new policy when updating
an existing one.
This causes the loss of previously set attributes that are
not passed in the update call.

This patch fixes this issue by getting existing qos policy object
instead of creating a new one for update.

This issue is already fixed in Pike branch with patch:
I57011bd4d40479855203061554090d19bb668960

Change-Id: I6f5a925084bb70b56e66d673eac2febdb38e0b34
Related-Bug: #1734136
"}]
commit_message:
Don't create new QoS policy during update operation

The QoS plugin erroneously creates a new policy when updating
an existing one.
This causes the loss of previously set attributes that are
not passed in the update call.

This patch fixes this issue by getting existing qos policy object
instead of creating a new one for update.

This issue is already fixed in Pike branch with patch:
I57011bd4d40479855203061554090d19bb668960

Change-Id: I6f5a925084bb70b56e66d673eac2febdb38e0b34
Related-Bug: #1734136

commit_message:
cluster-create support volume_type

Now we just parse the volume_type parameter in cluster/service.py,
but it is not passed in the creat instance, which will be
supported here.

Change-Id: Iae790e54ebf1bd6cb968c3be4c3f5cd53e1082f7
Partial-Bug: #1622957

commit_message:
Move default policies into code

This is part of a community effort to provide better user experience
for those having to maintain RBAC policy. More information on this
effort can be found below:

  https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/policy-in-code.html

bp policy-and-docs-in-code
Co-authored-By: Hieu LE <hieulq@vn.fujitsu.com>

subject: Revert "Revert "Add package install assertions to SUSE base image""
messages:
[{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 18:31:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 18:34:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 19:44:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 19:48:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2017-11-28 20:07:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

So, honestly I am not very comfortable with running systemd from TW on Leap. I mean, TW is a moving target and that means that the containers are also becoming a moving target. Moreover, this mix TW+Leap is not supported which means I will be unable to file bugs in the openSUSE bugzilla should anything breaks. And this is quite important since I was able to find and fix Leap bugs during OSA deployments. I know we use packages from some external repos but changing the init system from an unsupported repo may be a bit too much.

Also, since I was a bit late on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523346/, I would like to know what exactly is not working on systemd-228 in Leap because bug fixes are accepted in Leap :)

Finally, what about the zypper behavior? man page says that 'zypper in -y ...' is an an alias to 'zypper -n in' so the proposed change shouldn't make any difference. If it does, then there is a bug so please tell me so I can report it :)"}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 20:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-11-28 20:14:54.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

After considering the feedback from Markos I'm abandoning this change and will try and move forward in a different way."}]

commit_message:
Revert "Revert "Add package install assertions to SUSE base image""

Changes have been made to this revert to ensure we're installing the
needed packages to use the new version of systemd. This change also adds
more testing so we're doing everything we can combat regressions.

This reverts commit 6464003460f9bdc9f83876f0b133196b92cd8926.

Change-Id: I103a430b6bf7c63e817637f8604a8e0bb5ce22d8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
periodic py jobs for vmware-nsx ocata and pike

The vmware-nsx project would like to implement periodic jobs to verify
py27/py35 tests on stable branches (stable/pike, stable/ocata). This
patch adds the periodic job definitions to the vmware-nsx project
pipeline.

Change-Id: I6c88f895e4af4ea255df169ba060b28381a052d4

commit_message:
Check that network interface exsits before adjusting MTU

If the network interface does not exist or is removed,
adjusting the MTU will fail.

Change-Id: Ie4c7ba1929c78f7c433bf1827128a55f2a1386a3
