Thank you for the follow-up context Wan-yen!

At the Queens PTG I spoke with other driver maintainers and various cores regarding this specification and the logic behind it. We had fairly uniform consensus amongst all driver maintainers that that the role of the boot interface is to set properties based upon the requested or required user configuration, whatever they may be. There was also agreement that the boot interface should error when invalid configurations or unavailable configurations are called for.

As such, a separate UEFI+ISCSI only interface seems to run against the consensus of the community, especially because a configured node will not always boot to an iscsi volume. We still need to be able to boot IPA for cleaning or deployment if the requested boot lacks an iscsi volume target.

We agreed it would be moderately preferable to have common management interface calls to explicitly do the following things:

1) get/set boot device - Already part of management interface.
2) get/set boot mode in terms of UEFI/BIOS - Not presently part of the management interface, but we seemed to have a consensus that it should be exposed and available via the management interface.
3) get/set iscsi/fc/fcoe/hba/etc initiators as hardware boot devices - This needs to be proposed separately and generically since some vendors already support storage fabrics beyond iSCSI.

Each method could then have a default behavior to raise a NotSupported exception when called, and individual drivers could populate the necessary code inside their management interface methods. This ultimately would allow for cleaner interactions as time goes on and we are able to refactor boot/deploy interfaces to leverage those interfaces more generically.

Of course, in some cases as suggested by this specification, requested boot parameters may need to explicitly set as a single action, so a boot interface _could_ set a system into UEFI, and then when setting up booting from an iscsi volume, that boot interface could make specific calls based upon the requested configuration, which may result in an explicit UEFI+ISCSI call if that is the only scenario supported.

If other cases are requested that are not supported by the hardware such as BIOS+ISCSI, then the boot interface still ultimately needs to raise a NotSupported exception as the user has requested an invalid configuration via the properties that were posted to the instance_info field. We anticipate this changing over to traits in the future, but essentially serving the exact same purpose as a binary on/off representation.

While explicit general management interface methods would be preferable for each driver, we’re not explicitly requiring it as each driver has a slightly different scenario at this time. A driver could add the same functionality via common or specific boot interface code for feature parity and track it via an RFE. This is how iSCSI/FC boot support support was added for irmc, and we anticipate the ucs drivers taking the same path along with the idrac drivers in the future. Oneview also seemed to be on board with the same overall flow for now, although they indicated they needed to do a little more research as there is the aspect of storage fabric management that they need to investigate further.

I hope this explains the consensus we reached at the PTG as a community. If an explicit interface or method is desired then the possibility still exists further down the road but as with all major changes, it will take time and there are additional caveats/behaviors/logic that need to be made clear. Such as, how would a new interface handle no volume target information when a boot is requested? Is there anything that would force interfaces to be changed between tasks? What interface validation would require to pass? Et cetra.

If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out in IRC or here on this review.

-Julia'}, {'account_id': 22271, 'date': '2017-10-03 05:49:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 28:

Thanks Julia for comments, I changed the spec for ILO boot from volume only, please look at it'}, {'account_id': 22271, 'date': '2017-10-03 05:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 22271, 'date': '2017-10-03 05:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 22271, 'date': '2017-10-03 06:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31.'}, {'account_id': 11297, 'date': '2017-10-03 09:52:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Out-of-band Boot from UEFI iSCSI volume for HPE Proliant server

This change proposes to add a new methods in ilo management
interface to support out-of-band booting from iSCSI Cinder
volume for HPE Proliant Servers which supports booting from
UEFI iSCSI volume in firmware.

Co-Authored-By: Debayan Ray <debayan.ray@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Paresh Sao <paresh.h.sao@gmail.com>

Partial-Bug: 1526861
Change-Id: I86fb4fa7913cc7f925b2e450c81fb618135bf169

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 08:15:07.000000000', 'message': "Create cluster without using a failed task

Currently a new cluster is created by using a try/rescue
operation which always fails for a new cluster, causing
a lot of confusion due to the failed task report.

This patch implements an improvement which tests the
cluster state and creates a new one if it is not ready
without requiring the task to fail.

As the cluster creation is a single task, it's merged
into the rabbitmq_cluster.yml task file.

As the tags are all the same, the tag is set in the
main task file instead of individually on all the tasks.

Change-Id: Iaa8e429cbd1c539d8242453c0490373c758dd9fe
(cherry picked from commit 3b897ad51551f47d3e11cf182c5ecfe14d3130af)
"}]
commit_message:
Create cluster without using a failed task

Currently a new cluster is created by using a try/rescue
operation which always fails for a new cluster, causing
a lot of confusion due to the failed task report.

This patch implements an improvement which tests the
cluster state and creates a new one if it is not ready
without requiring the task to fail.

As the cluster creation is a single task, it's merged
into the rabbitmq_cluster.yml task file.

As the tags are all the same, the tag is set in the
main task file instead of individually on all the tasks.

Change-Id: Iaa8e429cbd1c539d8242453c0490373c758dd9fe
(cherry picked from commit 3b897ad51551f47d3e11cf182c5ecfe14d3130af)

commit_message:
Add a tempest plugin gate job

This adds check and gate jobs using the new Tempest plugin to CloudKitty.
The jobs are non-voting for now.

Change-Id: I455eb7208fb97c140b94db9ae53f9da2cd87de82

commit_message:
Change plan files whitelist when creating plan

This change removes files whitelisting when creating/updating plan
using 'Local Folder' option to avoid problems with missing files
in case a new file with non listed extension is added to
tripleo-heat-templates. Instead, we're blacklisting a set of filepaths
which we're sure we can omit from deployment plan.

Closes-Bug: 1734676
Change-Id: Ie0cc450dcad2ec2cae7c15daffe362dfca255f6f
(cherry picked from commit cf7dda42eaddc9444cdb5bb1176aa91692eef557)

commit_message:
Add ability to disable implementing pip.conf

On something like the repo server we do not want to
change the default pip settings so that we allow
the global pip.conf or default pip settings to do
the right things.

Change-Id: I7bd31f2d89d3fe9d48e32c79ddef7a8ef1392eb7

commit_message:
Add ability to set the default index

In this patch we allow the default index to be
changed so that we can set it to the repo server
when the pypi reverse proxy is available to be
used.

The repeated implementation of the find-links
in the install section is removed as it is
unnecessary - the global find-links option
applies there too.

Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Change-Id: I56f22f46ff849a7049ac7ae873af7a4bc526fa63
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

commit_message:
Rework drivers page in the admin documentation

First, "Enabling Drivers" is a really confusing title, since this page
links to complete driver documentation. It also links to IPA docs and
the PXE driver interface.

Next, our documentation is full of remarks about e.g. "pxe_* family of
drivers", which are misleading in the presence of hardware types and
the pxe_agent_cimc driver. We also have mentions of "iscsi deploy method"
without detailed explanation of how this method relates to hardware types
and classic drivers.

This change consolidates drivers and interfaces documentation under
the more clearly named root page. A new page is created with sections for
both deploy interfaces to use for linking from wherever a link to
a particular deploy interface is required.

Change-Id: Ifb8328ccaaac443fac276873e2c375ebcf983f03

The upgrade_task that remove packages have a when clause that is

commit_message:
Handle 'false' in when statements for ansible upgrade_tasks

The upgrade_task that remove packages have a when clause that is
set from the UpgradeRemoveUnusedPackages parameter. When we write
the overcloud config and translate "tags: step" to "when: step"
we must be careful to handle these tasks otherwise we get errors.
See the bug for more info.

Change-Id: Ic10ae0f3262a93ceec6ba8d938f36c937f3b594c
Closes-Bug: 1734118
(cherry picked from commit 2a9012a3f0ffcac7d946581b68f14daf118939c3)

commit_message:
Resolve ansible-lint test failures

With the merge of https://review.openstack.org/520177 in the
tests repo some ansible-lint failures which previously were
not being picked up are now detected.

This adds the appropriate skip tags to the tasks so that they
are not evaluated by ansible-lint.

Change-Id: Ia91f73d4f17e94a150c93c75c618778c25823d0d
(cherry picked from commit 299213ba23fb7e6b8ab064201dc977f0ed50df23)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 170, 'name': 'Mike Perez', 'email': 'thingee@gmail.com', 'username': 'thingee'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 6159, 'name': 'Flavio Percoco Premoli', 'email': 'fpercoco@redhat.com', 'username': 'flaper87'}, {'_account_id': 6482, 'name': 'Steve Martinelli', 'email': 's.martinelli@gmail.com', 'username': 'stevemar'}, {'_account_id': 6637, 'name': 'Sam Betts', 'email': 'sam@code-smash.net', 'username': 'sambetts'}, {'_account_id': 21439, 'name': 'Armando Dominguez', 'email': 'armando.dominguez@rackspace.com', 'username': 'armando.dominguez'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-08-31 14:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-08-31 14:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-governance-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/09/363709/1/check/gate-governance-docs-ubuntu-xenial/c667307//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 49s'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-09-02 10:36:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from networking-cisco to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2016-09-02 15:43:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is a simple re-add, it should go through the standard application and evaluation process.  The project's former inclusion in the Neutron Stadium is useful for history but is not an automatic stand-alone inclusion into projects.yaml."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2016-09-05 07:05:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree with Dean here. I believe this project should go through a normal project addition process.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-09-05 15:51:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with Dean & Flavio. The original inclusion of this project was under the "Neutron stadium" concept, which originally triggered a small controversy with the Technical Committee when it was introduced. We felt that it delegated too much project acceptance criteria to the Neutron drivers, that some subteams would operate as separate silos, and we doubted that Neutron core reviewers would be able to vouch for everything done under the stadium. That said, back then we decided to let the experiment proceed, so that it would fail or succeed on its own merit. 

That decision didn't imply automatic acceptance by the TC of future stadium splits though, so I think we should still evaluate if those split project teams follow OpenStack principles under our normal evaluation rules.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-09-06 10:33:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looking at the proposal, I have two concerns (which I'll elaborate on during the TC meeting today): the timing of the proposal (between FF and release is the worst timing to add a new project team), and whether this project team provides a level and open collaboration playing field."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2016-09-06 12:17:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Sam,

Do you think you can update the commit message to provide all the required info for evaluating new projects properly?

Here's an example: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/353693/

Thank you"}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-09-06 14:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-09-06 14:42:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the comments, I've updated the commit message with information regarding the new project requirements, and I'll be attending the TC meeting to discuss this further."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-06 14:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-governance-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/09/363709/2/check/gate-governance-docs-ubuntu-xenial/f4cb341//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 24s
- gate-governance-tox-validate-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/09/363709/2/check/gate-governance-tox-validate-ubuntu-xenial/25e9e9a/ : FAILURE in 3m 27s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-09-07 09:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from networking-cisco to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-09-07 09:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

During the meeting on Sept 6 we decided to delay this request until the start of Ocata, since the period between cycles is not the right time to add new project teams.

This should give us the time to clarify our overall stance on whether drivers interfacing with proprietary technologies belong "in" OpenStack, as every team (nova, cinder, neutron...) seems to have a slightly different approach there.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2016-10-13 23:53:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1 Rollcall-Vote+1

(2 comments)

I might be the right time to evaluate again this application.
I'm voting +1 now, as I found the level of open collaboration pretty good. No blocker on my side until now."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2016-10-17 13:52:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We should probably wait until we meet in barcelona? (https://www.openstack.org/summit/barcelona-2016/summit-schedule/events/16921/cross-project-workshops-where-to-draw-the-line-for-proprietary-code-with-drivers)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-11-01 18:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Although I am in favor of finding a way to make it possible to bring the Cisco team back into the tent, at this point I'm afraid it would be blocked by our rule "The project shall not benefit a single vendor, or a single vendors product offerings...".

Some members of the TC did discuss this informally at the summit, and we are going to work on a path forward. Until that is done, I can't vote +1 on this change.'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-11-15 17:08:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We need to circle back to this patch with what was discussed in barcelona. Adding armando (and another accidentally) since it impacts neutron.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-11-28 18:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Please see the discussion on the ML thread starting with http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-November/108074.html'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-12-28 00:23:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sam, there is an effort to begin recognizing what tests go with which network vendor type in Neutron. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/391594/1

This would start an effort of providing validation on drivers, which we do not have today. If we can begin getting something like this going, I think it would begin to put us on the right track of allowing an interested party in the community to validate drivers to be marked as "OpenStack compatible" like Cinder drivers have today.

It was also explained to me at the summit that someone from Cisco wanted their driver setup to be documented at docs.o.o, but they can't today because of legacy reasons the docs team has for the drivers being out of tree. Once we are able to validate drivers, we know which drivers are working and current and could work with the docs team on knowing which drivers are official that we should providing documentation for. Instead of customers have to go through the pain of finding documentation on vendor x's site to use with OpenStack.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-05-03 03:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Removed the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
* Rollcall-Vote+1 by Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2017-06-27 09:12:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Can this patch be abandoned and restored when it's ready for review?"}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-11-28 13:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning for now'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2016-08-31 14:27:05.000000000', 'message': 'Add networking-cisco back into the Big Tent

networking-cisco was previously under the neutron stadium, it was
removed from this by commit 396c0df1654767912134d77e697ced0ffff557d1. A
consequence of no longer being under the neutron stadium was that we
were also removed from the Big Tent, this patch re-adds networking-cisco
to the Big Tent as an independent project as we want to continue to be
an official OpenStack project.

Change-Id: Icc14b06b248d95c14fdb2a6ba4029a8dda959f44
'}, {'created': '2016-09-06 14:39:55.000000000', 'message': "Add networking-cisco back into the Big Tent

networking-cisco was previously under the neutron stadium, it was
removed from this by commit 396c0df1654767912134d77e697ced0ffff557d1. A
consequence of no longer being under the neutron stadium was that we
were also removed from the Big Tent, this patch is to add networking-cisco
to the Big Tent as an independent project as we want to continue to be
an official OpenStack project.

Open Source:
License: Apache 2.0 License
Libraries: On top of what neutron requires, networking-cisco also
requires:
- UcsSdk (Apache-2.0)
- ncclient (Apache-2.0)
- apicapi (Apache-2.0)

Open Community:
Our current active contributors are mostly from Cisco, but we strive to
keep the project open to all developers by tracking features and bugs on
our launchpad and reviewing patches without bias.  We are currently
working to organise weekly IRC meetings for networking-cisco to increase
our community presence. Several of our developers are active in Neutron
and the wider OpenStack community, and some of our cores are core
members of other OpenStack projects including neutron-vpnaas, ironic and
magnum-ui.

Open Development:
networking-cisco is integrated with OpenStack CI and was created
according to the project creator's guide. We track our features, bugs
and milestones via the launchpad page created as part of the guide. We
thoroughly review all code that gets merged in networking-cisco using
the gerrit review system, and require at least two core +2s to allow a
merge. networking-cisco uses OpenStack libraries, development patterns
and hacking rules, to ensure we align with other OpenStack projects.

Open Design:
Much of our initial code development was done as part of the Neutron
code tree before the neutron vendor decomposition, because of this a
large part of the design of the plugins/drivers in networking-cisco
happened alongside the design of Neutron and the ML2 plugin. Even after
the decomposition, our architecture has continued to be largely dictated
by changes in Neutron itself, which we continue to be involved with.
Other design discussions often happen on gerrit, and we plan to increase
our presence on the #openstack-networking-cisco channel for this sort of
thing too.

Interoperability:
networking-cisco is a library of plugins and drivers for OpenStack
neutron, and interaction with our code is via the neutron API and
neutron API and client extensions we provide.

Testing:
All python code merged into networking-cisco must be supported by unit
testing which are run in the CI on every patch, as well as passing the
python pep8 syntax checks. On top of this testing we also aim to provide
Third Party CI for each of our drivers/plugins to ensure that we are
testing the networking-cisco code in real world scenarios using tempest.

Change-Id: Icc14b06b248d95c14fdb2a6ba4029a8dda959f44
"}]
commit_message:
Add networking-cisco back into the Big Tent

networking-cisco was previously under the neutron stadium, it was
removed from this by commit 396c0df1654767912134d77e697ced0ffff557d1. A
consequence of no longer being under the neutron stadium was that we
were also removed from the Big Tent, this patch is to add networking-cisco
to the Big Tent as an independent project as we want to continue to be
an official OpenStack project.

Open Source:
License: Apache 2.0 License
Libraries: On top of what neutron requires, networking-cisco also
requires:
- UcsSdk (Apache-2.0)
- ncclient (Apache-2.0)
- apicapi (Apache-2.0)

Open Community:
Our current active contributors are mostly from Cisco, but we strive to
keep the project open to all developers by tracking features and bugs on
our launchpad and reviewing patches without bias.  We are currently
working to organise weekly IRC meetings for networking-cisco to increase
our community presence. Several of our developers are active in Neutron
and the wider OpenStack community, and some of our cores are core
members of other OpenStack projects including neutron-vpnaas, ironic and
magnum-ui.

Open Development:
networking-cisco is integrated with OpenStack CI and was created
according to the project creator's guide. We track our features, bugs
and milestones via the launchpad page created as part of the guide. We
thoroughly review all code that gets merged in networking-cisco using
the gerrit review system, and require at least two core +2s to allow a
merge. networking-cisco uses OpenStack libraries, development patterns
and hacking rules, to ensure we align with other OpenStack projects.

Open Design:
Much of our initial code development was done as part of the Neutron
code tree before the neutron vendor decomposition, because of this a
large part of the design of the plugins/drivers in networking-cisco
happened alongside the design of Neutron and the ML2 plugin. Even after
the decomposition, our architecture has continued to be largely dictated
by changes in Neutron itself, which we continue to be involved with.
Other design discussions often happen on gerrit, and we plan to increase
our presence on the #openstack-networking-cisco channel for this sort of
thing too.

Interoperability:
networking-cisco is a library of plugins and drivers for OpenStack
neutron, and interaction with our code is via the neutron API and
neutron API and client extensions we provide.

Testing:
All python code merged into networking-cisco must be supported by unit
testing which are run in the CI on every patch, as well as passing the
python pep8 syntax checks. On top of this testing we also aim to provide
Third Party CI for each of our drivers/plugins to ensure that we are
testing the networking-cisco code in real world scenarios using tempest.

Change-Id: Icc14b06b248d95c14fdb2a6ba4029a8dda959f44

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10342, 'date': '2017-01-30 20:45:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

Is there a reason we're OK with pushing up a breaking change to (mis)users of our API without hiding it behind a micro version change? I understand the behavior was unintended, but it still breaks our contract to change that behavior without a version bump, right?"}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2017-01-30 21:12:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

Jay has a good point. We have to be better at knowing where to draw the line wrt bugs/backwards compat/micro change.

Looks like 3 choices:
1. treat as bug and make this change. Con: break someone's misuse of this. What I don't understand is whether the user thinks they are giving the chassis uuid or a node uuid :)
2. deprecate the 2nd call, invoke the first call instead. And then delete in Pike.
3. add a version bump, starting from new version, the 2nd one is not supported."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2017-01-30 21:15:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

If it isn't clear what we should do, I think it is worth discussing in our next ironic meeting."}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2017-01-30 21:47:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

We already did this in https://review.openstack.org/314514. From what I see, this is a bug, and I'd prefer not to do any deprecation for behaviour that should not have been used at all, and apart from that, introduced issues in API. We did not advertise the ways of doing things this patch removes anywhere, so I personally am OK with just changing this stuff as proposed here.

Also, IIRC people were OK with treating it as a bug when this was discussed, but it was a while ago, and I can't remember where to look for this discussion."}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-01-31 12:22:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19: Patch Set 18 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-31 13:26:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Verified-1

[{'created': '2016-05-13 15:03:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix invalid chassis/nodes/chassis_uuid API url

Right now v1/chassis/<uuid_id>/nodes and
v1/chassis/nodes/<uuid_id> both work as a URLs in our API, the second
version of the URL does the same as the first, however it shouldn't even
exist as it exists purly as a side effect of how we've programmed the
API controllers. This patch corrects the controllers to ensure only
supported routes work.

Change-Id: I9885feef5fb305e87faeff3deec0a78015c565b8

commit_message:
Fix invalid chassis/nodes/chassis_uuid API url

Currently the two routes

v1/chassis/<chassis_uuid>/nodes
v1/chassis/nodes/<chassis_uuid>

are supported and have identical behavior. The second only exists as a
side-effect of our implementation, and should not be supported. This
patch removes the second route.

Partial-Bug: #1580997
Change-Id: I9885feef5fb305e87faeff3deec0a78015c565b8

subject: Fix all possible node subresources routing collisions

commit_message:
Fix all possible node subresources routing collisions

This patch corrects all remaining nodes subresource APIs that collide
with node names. Validate and Detail are now the only remaining names
that must continue to be disallowed.

Partial-Bug: #1580997
Change-Id: I0aef37d66b33eb7ef916cf0333c580bfbce48efc

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 08:16:50.000000000', 'message': "Remove selfcheck.json

The file selfcheck.json has no discernable purpose,
so it is removed. The file pip-selfcheck.json is
automatically created by pip and used to track
when last it checked if it's on the latest version.

The tags implemented in the role are also corrected
to ensure that the placement of the pip.conf file
is considered a 'config' task, not an 'install'
task. The sub-tags are removed as they are unnecessary.

Change-Id: I53ad3a9c50071a34286f2351f5f245f272c07638
(cherry picked from commit 4e7e23f6e99d542468774cc4708522f330972908)

commit_message:
Remove selfcheck.json

The file selfcheck.json has no discernable purpose,
so it is removed. The file pip-selfcheck.json is
automatically created by pip and used to track
when last it checked if it's on the latest version.

The tags implemented in the role are also corrected
to ensure that the placement of the pip.conf file
is considered a 'config' task, not an 'install'
task. The sub-tags are removed as they are unnecessary.

Change-Id: I53ad3a9c50071a34286f2351f5f245f272c07638
(cherry picked from commit 4e7e23f6e99d542468774cc4708522f330972908)

subject: Process client broker requests post bootstrap
messages: [{'account_id': 935, 'date': '2017-11-28 10:58:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2017-11-28 13:32:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 10:58:41.000000000', 'message': 'Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: Id412a6b3503e00bd870ccb8f3acc5f3957c23f5d
Closes-Bug: 1734620
(cherry picked from commit 9d095b31d98a61fccc1064ef878a0f4bf8263aac)
'}]
commit_message:
Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: Id412a6b3503e00bd870ccb8f3acc5f3957c23f5d
Closes-Bug: 1734620
(cherry picked from commit 9d095b31d98a61fccc1064ef878a0f4bf8263aac)

commit_message:
Extend tests vars overrides

This ensures that our group vars are well applied.
This check is useful to ensure the default inventory loads fine,
which would fail to apply group vars if it wasn't loading properly.

Change-Id: Idc1a2be1ee761ed01c3b54547fd3be804b0c0c33

commit_message:
Update tox_install.sh to align for sphinx jobs

The updates to the sphinx docs jobs in support of the updates to
the PTI wound up exposing an unintended interface. There are two flavors
of the tox_install.sh file out there, and we basically need to collapse
them into one flavor.

Update the tox_install.sh script to match the
constraints-as-first-argument form.

Change-Id: I7cb4b44952713752435e1faf0f63bf0d37e7dda6

commit_message:
Add 'description' in share type APIs

This fix add attr 'description' in list/create share
type APIs.

Change-Id: I39705acbfca812b66d74fbd2fee228a7a85bc2d8
Closes-Bug: #1724183

'}, {'created': '2017-10-25 15:08:24.000000000', 'message': '[placement] Document the changes to PUT and GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

Add to placement-api-ref and the rest_api_version_history and create
a reno note for the request body format of PUT
/allocations/{consumer_uuid} in microversion 1.11 and the related
changes to GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid} (which added project_id
and user_id).

Change-Id: I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
'}, {'created': '2017-10-26 18:54:54.000000000', 'message': '[placement] Symmetric GET and PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

In a new microversion, 1.11, include project_id and user_id in the
output of GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid} and add JSON schema
to enable PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid} using the same dict-based
format for request body that is used in the GET response. In later
commits a similar format will be used in POST /allocations. This
symmetry is general good form and also will make client code a little
easier.

Internally to handlers/allocation.py the same method (_set_allocations)
is used for every microversion. Any previous data structure is
transformed into the dict-ish form. This means that pre-existing tests
(like allocation-bad-class.yaml) continue to exercise the problems it
was made for, but needs to be pinned to an older microversion, rather than
being latest.

Info about these changes is added to placement-api-ref,
rest_api_version_history and a reno note.

Change-Id: I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
Closes-Bug: #1708204
'}, {'created': '2017-10-29 11:23:29.000000000', 'message': '[placement] Symmetric GET and PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

been updated as well, to change the 'allocation_requests' object
to use the dict-based format.

commit_message:
[placement] Symmetric GET and PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}

In a new microversion, 1.12, include project_id and user_id in the
output of GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid} and add JSON schema
to enable PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid} using the same dict-based
format for request body that is used in the GET response. In later
commits a similar format will be used in POST /allocations. This
symmetry is general good form and also will make client code a little
easier.

Since GET /allocation_candiates includes objects which are capable
of being PUT to /allocations/{consumer_uuid}, its response body has
been updated as well, to change the 'allocation_requests' object
to use the dict-based format.

Internally to handlers/allocation.py the same method (_set_allocations)
is used for every microversion. Any previous data structure is
transformed into the dict-ish form. This means that pre-existing tests
(like allocation-bad-class.yaml) continue to exercise the problems it
was made for, but needs to be pinned to an older microversion, rather than
being latest.

Info about these changes is added to placement-api-ref,
rest_api_version_history and a reno.

Change-Id: I49f5680c15413bce27f2abba68b699f3ea95dcdc
Implements: bp symmetric-allocations
Closes-Bug: #1708204

commit_message:
Mount a tmpfs filesystem for heat tmpfiles

We noticed that heat was sleeping a lot waiting on disk.  By putting the sqlite
database on a ramdisk (tmpfs) we cut the deploy time in half.

Change-Id: Ic22bf49787279993d5d6ee081b31d789b519e555

commit_message:
Add the possibility to specify a full path for the playbook.

It's sometime useful to have your playbook in a non-standard
directory.  This add the possibility to specifiy a full path for
OPT_PLAYBOOK and still doing the right thing.

Change-Id: Ic9fb78f13cd387831c417071ed1787cf2c3c0136

commit_message:
Use EnpointMap port to create firewall rules.

Currently the firewall rules are hardcoded.  This make any
modification to the endpoint map by the user useless as the firewall
will block his/her new port.

This fetch the relevent port from the endpoint map to adjust the
firewall rule to what the user may define.

Change-Id: I5a89af5963382cba7ce4f44986c2953824be6869

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-18 22:03:47.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Ensure openstack-nova-compute stopped during batch compute upgrade.

After running yum upgrade, systemd will constantly restart
nova-compute as the configuration is not right and the service fails
to boot.

At some point puppet will start to update the configuration.  This may
lead to inconsistent configuration as puppet is not really in charge
of restarting the service as systemd is.

This can lead to a complete blockage of the upgrade where the partly
modified configuration has been taken by a systemd lead nova restart.

This make sure that systemd won't try to restart the openstack nova
compute service while the configuration is not updated.

Change-Id: I983e69116a5cd41e8f240d868c4dd287beef9a05
"}, {'created': '2017-08-02 08:26:31.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Ensure openstack-nova-compute stopped during batch compute upgrade.

After running yum upgrade, systemd will constantly restart
nova-compute as the configuration is not right and the service fails
to boot.

At some point puppet will start to update the configuration.  This may
lead to inconsistent configuration as puppet is not really in charge
of restarting the service as systemd is.

This can lead to a complete blockage of the upgrade where the partly
modified configuration has been taken by a systemd lead nova restart.

This make sure that systemd won't try to restart the openstack nova
compute service while the configuration is not updated.

Change-Id: I983e69116a5cd41e8f240d868c4dd287beef9a05
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Ensure openstack-nova-compute stopped during batch compute upgrade.

After running yum upgrade, systemd will constantly restart
nova-compute as the configuration is not right and the service fails
to boot.

At some point puppet will start to update the configuration.  This may
lead to inconsistent configuration as puppet is not really in charge
of restarting the service as systemd is.

This can lead to a complete blockage of the upgrade where the partly
modified configuration has been taken by a systemd lead nova restart.

This make sure that systemd won't try to restart the openstack nova
compute service while the configuration is not updated.

Change-Id: I983e69116a5cd41e8f240d868c4dd287beef9a05

commit_message:
Make rolling update interactive.

In the previous heat driven workflow the rolling update was
interactive.  This restore this behavior using ansible prompt idiom.

Change-Id: Icedfbc0f1f4bfb9a123a847f9f0d8a2077d2d992

commit_message:
Add parameter ExtraHostFileEntries

This allows passing hosts entries from an external stack, or
that references other external nodes.  This is useful in the
case where you want to split e.g controlplane nodes from compute
or similar.

As an example you could do something like this to generate an
environment file:

openstack stack output show controlplane HostsEntry | grep controller\
 | sed "s/|//g" | sed "s/^ */    - /" \
 | sed "1s/^/parameter_defaults:\n  ExtraHostFileEntries:\n/"

Change-Id: If26f87e3384e242ae637650adce7c5dba1611cdf

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 09:28:41.000000000', 'message': "Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I1442656b3e4ab84ee5c219f5f4959bd7f41f01fe
"}]
commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I1442656b3e4ab84ee5c219f5f4959bd7f41f01fe

commit_message:
Allow empty list of enabled_roles

This is the case when creating a compute-only stack with the default roles data

E.g:

openstack overcloud roles generate --roles-path tripleo-heat-templates/roles -o compute_only_roles_data.yaml Compute
openstack overcloud deploy --templates tripleo-heat-templates --stack compute1 -r compute_only_roles_data.yaml

Change-Id: I44e6450c1afe8fb972731e46b40fc2e63b320a5b

commit_message:
Use admin context to update ports

The port might contains security groups created by Kuryr-libnetwork
in service tenant. Therefore, adding security group via port update
needs admin context.

Change-Id: I83b387ee1143374306ed3fbb93a29f8adcd3a54f

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 19:03:04.000000000', 'message': 'Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

Change-Id: Ic13823aa65a8bc7acb2e631b8e53149285d0d467
'}]
commit_message:
Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

Change-Id: Ic13823aa65a8bc7acb2e631b8e53149285d0d467

They shouldn't be here. We control the image names via tripleo-common.

commit_message:
Fix the format file name

The file name should be marked follow [1]
as consistent with their semantic meaning.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/rst-conv/inline-markups.html#file-name-and-path

Change-Id: Ief3c3960034fe76fe2e3b2deda45ffd7906966db

commit_message:
Add networking-generic-switch under ironic

this project has become an essential part of ironic testing,
and ironic community would like to formally pull it under
OpenStack baremetal program.

For more rationale and discussion see this ML thread:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124519.html

Change-Id: Ie08c9ef029e29845c766d9c10329817124954e16

commit_message:
Update Blazar's document references

Blazar uses the official documentation site since Blazar became
an OpenStack official project. This patch replaces old documentation
url with the official url.

Change-Id: I064a80adbcf429c0c2e87b8b6afca0e512c799ca

subject: Remove stable:follows-policy from Kolla
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 167, 'name': 'Christian Berendt', 'email': 'berendt@osism.tech', 'username': 'berendt'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 979, 'name': 'Dave Walker', 'email': 'email@daviey.com', 'username': 'davewalker'}, {'_account_id': 1390, 'name': 'Paul Bourke', 'email': 'pauldbourke@proton.me', 'username': 'pauldbourke'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 2834, 'name': 'Steven Dake', 'email': 'steven.dake@gmail.com', 'username': 'sdake'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 6159, 'name': 'Flavio Percoco Premoli', 'email': 'fpercoco@redhat.com', 'username': 'flaper87'}, {'_account_id': 7488, 'name': 'Jeffrey Zhang', 'email': 'zhang.lei.fly@gmail.com', 'username': 'Jeffrey4l'}, {'_account_id': 8157, 'name': 'Bertrand LALLAU', 'email': 'bertrand.lallau@gmail.com', 'username': 'blallau'}, {'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 10787, 'name': 'Michal Jastrzebski (inc0)', 'email': 'michal.jastrzebski@intel.com', 'username': 'inc0'}, {'_account_id': 11105, 'name': 'Swapnil Kulkarni', 'email': 'coolsvap@gmail.com', 'username': 'coolsvap'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11869, 'name': 'zhubingbing', 'email': 'zhu.bingbing@99cloud.net', 'username': 'zhubingbing'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 13039, 'name': 'Martin André', 'email': 'm.andre@redhat.com', 'username': 'mandre'}, {'_account_id': 13642, 'name': 'Vikram Hosakote', 'email': 'vhosakot@cisco.com', 'username': 'vhosakot'}, {'_account_id': 16233, 'name': 'Mauricio Lima', 'email': 'mauriciolimab@gmail.com', 'username': 'limamauricio'}, {'_account_id': 16620, 'name': 'Alicja Kwasniewska', 'email': 'alicja.kwasniewska@intel.com', 'username': 'akwasnie'}, {'_account_id': 19316, 'name': 'Eduardo Gonzalez', 'email': 'dabarren@gmail.com', 'username': 'egonzalez90'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22582, 'name': 'Duong Ha-Quang', 'email': 'quangduongha@gmail.com', 'username': 'duonghq'}, {'_account_id': 23717, 'name': 'Surya Prakash Singh', 'email': 'singh.surya64mnnit@gmail.com', 'username': 'SuryaPrakash'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-11-14 15:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-11-14 15:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We should have the PTL approve this change, but I do think this was the direction we agreed to go.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-11-14 16:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-11-15 09:00:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

If possible I'd like to keep the stable:follows-policy tag for the container image project."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2017-11-15 10:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-15 11:29:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Re: the objection that the tag should be kept for kolla-the-container-image-tool:

The value of the stable policy (and associated tag) is to communicate to deployers of OpenStack that they can upgrade to newer versions of OpenStack components on a stable branch with relative confidence. It is therefore relevant for components deployed in a cloud setup, not the tools that are used to deploy it or build the deployment images.

As far as I can tell, openstack/kolla delivers tooling to build container images of OpenStack components: I therefore think that the tag should not be applied to it.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-11-15 16:49:29.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Rollcall-Vote+1 by Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 10787, 'date': '2017-11-20 17:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Just few weeks after we got it:)'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2017-11-22 15:10:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

(1 comment)

Let's remove the tag for k-ansible only"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-11-22 15:16:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Flavio's comment confused me. We said we would not have this tags for downstream projects, like packaging, installers, etc.
kolla-ansible is one of them if I understand correctly.

FWIW, TripleO also have libraries and CLI tools, with API but we said in Sydney these tools don't suit for this tag."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2017-11-23 08:11:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I might be the one confused! I just re-read Thierry's comment and I see Kolla falls into that category. After thinking about this a bit longer, I now think it makes sense.

kolla is a tool that helps building container images, therefore it's a tool related to deployment and shipping of the services we produce.

kolla-ansible and kolla-kubernetes are both deployment tools.

They all fall into the same category, I believe. Changing my vote, sorry for the confusion."}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-11-23 17:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thierry and all, sorry for the delay responding here.

When I was talking about the API, I was referring to the config.json that kolla_start parses and let you customize the containers at runtime, such as:
- copy files in the container
- set permissions and ownership
- set the command that is going to be run in the container

We make heavy use of this feature in TripleO, and I would be sad if kolla breaks it without following the proper deprecation policy. I hope this clarifies a bit.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-11-23 17:20:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Martin, it's the same thing for Puppet modules and the parameters, used by TripleO etc. I think the whole point of this discussion is that we agreed that this tag doesn't suit for projects like installers / packaging."}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2017-11-24 00:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-11-24 07:51:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Emilien, I see your point and how the containers images produced via kolla are somewhat similar to the puppet modules in that aspect.

IMO the commit message could be slightly improved, as it puts both kolla the container images project and kolla-* the deployment tools in the same bag and and maintains the confusion around what Kolla really does.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> IMO the commit message could be slightly improved, as it puts both kolla the container images project and kolla-* the deployment tools in the same bag

Is a container images project not also a deployment tool, or a piece of a deployment tool? I see them as in the same bag.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:38:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

While there was no formal objection (and therefore this should be approved by now under our lazy consensus rule) I'll let a couple more days pass, in case Colleen wants to more formally object and this needs further discussion."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-11-24 11:49:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

commit_message:
Remove stable:follows-policy from Kolla

During the OpenStack Summit in Sydney, we discussed about what operators
expect from the stable policy.
One of the outputs, documented here [1], was that projects like
installers don't need the tag.
The tag has been created for service projects with an API.

This patch removes the tag from Kolla, which was the only remaining
deployment tool project with this tag.
We'll also have to update the Software Catalog (on openstack.org) to
make sure it doesn't show the tag as missing.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/SYD-stable-policy

Change-Id: If4803d14db0c51c83789df302fdb0471d72fb824

[{'created': '2017-11-20 00:29:59.000000000', 'message': 'Remove releasenotes/requirements.txt

In change Iaa917d4f126d24c701cd3b8b0edfba4d4e0ca9c1 we have the
proposal to not to install releasenotes/requirements.txt as projects
should not really need any extra requirements to produce releasenotes
other than reno itself being installed and available.

Remove the references to this requirements.txt file so the CI
implementation does not get out of sync with policy.  As noted by
AJaeger in the other change, not repo uses this as yet.

Change-Id: Ieab3dfde7854d76dded6b1f8dd3aab1f1071b208
Needed-by: Iaa917d4f126d24c701cd3b8b0edfba4d4e0ca9c1
'}]
commit_message:
Remove releasenotes/requirements.txt

In change Iaa917d4f126d24c701cd3b8b0edfba4d4e0ca9c1 we have the
proposal to not to install releasenotes/requirements.txt as projects
should not really need any extra requirements to produce releasenotes
other than reno itself being installed and available.

Remove the references to this requirements.txt file so the CI
implementation does not get out of sync with policy.  As noted by
AJaeger in the other change, not repo uses this as yet.

Change-Id: Ieab3dfde7854d76dded6b1f8dd3aab1f1071b208
Needed-by: Iaa917d4f126d24c701cd3b8b0edfba4d4e0ca9c1

commit_message:
Add pre_test_grenade_hook

The br-ex is not brought up by ODL, when devstack creates
initial neutron networks, which end up in failure of tempest
tests, due to floating ip inaccessibility. This is work around
which adds a hook to bring the external bridge up, delete initial
networks and re create netwoks at the end of stack.sh. This hook
can be reverted once the br-ex bringup gets in order.

Change-Id: Id335dc34e00c0109efaf191c97c5306cd177ed4a

into the TaskManager. For normal operation this is a passthrough/no-op

commit_message:
Use task_manager and Adapter from shade

As a stepping-stone towards shade and sdk codepaths being rationalized,
we need to get SDK using the Adapter from shade that submits requests
into the TaskManager. For normal operation this is a passthrough/no-op
sort of thing, but it's essential for high-volume consumers such as
nodepool.

This exposes a bunch of places in tests where we're mocking a bit too
deeply. We should go back through and fix all of those via
requests_mock, but that's WAY too much for today.

This was a 'for later' task, but it turns out that the move to Adapter
was causing exceptions to be thrown that were not the exceptions that
were intended to be caught in the SDK layer, which was causing
functional tests of things like GET operations to fail. So it became a
today task.

Change-Id: I169609eb5992e2fbae1caa91cb9fced1d42d3383

commit_message:
Remove legacy jobs from oaktree repos

The legacy jobs are actually broken currently, but the path forward for
them is to make nice new shiny ones. So go ahead and remove these.

Also, remove publish-to-pypi-quietly from oaktreemodel as oaktreemodel
will need a special build step before doing PyPI publication and that's
better suited for once we've done the base jobs.

Change-Id: I4c73e196b248d391549053beb7801bb8cb5e082a
Needed-By: Iee5f9b54d5c456ad5925f485b80f8e70accf962a

commit_message:
Fix Gnocchi support ceph

Based on gnocchi issue #412 [0], cradox is more stable and recommended
to use.

* Add cradox for source and  RHEL family distro binary.
* Ubuntu binary lacks of cradox package, so install from pypi

[0] https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/issues/412

Co-Authored-By: Jeffrey Zhang <zhang.lei.fly@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Icf7d6425884fb889d48c786caebbfc7b7050ae8e
Closes-Bug: #1718701

commit_message:
remove non-voting from experimental jobs

Experimental jobs are always non-voting, remove the attribute, it's not
needed at all.

Update the linter to handle experimental and periodic-stable pipelines
as well.

Change-Id: Ia00fdbf998402494df2f3e208090484a7cfcfc53

commit_message:
Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The updates to the sphinx docs jobs in support of the updates to
the PTI wound up exposing an unintended interface. There are a few flavors
of the tox_install.sh file out there, and we basically need to collapse
them into one flavor.

Copy in the most widely used version of the script.

Change-Id: I9f952101645c91109bda3c5a43216168321003eb

commit_message:
Fix static-inventory option for minor update

The generate-inventory is always true in the current
code, when we want to provide a static inventory
it won't be taken in account.
the patch aim to fix this bug

Cherry-pick from:
If204b3da9b279d7b001d8cfe8c77106f8bf594af

Change-Id: If204b3da9b279d7b001d8cfe8c77106f8bf594af

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-07 10:46:51.000000000', 'message': 'Used cached git sources and enable depends-on

Many, many patches have gone into the master branch to
enable the use of depends-on for role tests and to make
use of the git clones put into place by zuul. This patch
ensures that this functionality is now available for this
branch too.

The primary benefit for doing this would be to make use
of the cached git clones provided by zuul to improve test
reliability.

The secondary benefit would be to have the ability to
use depends-on to test patches together.

However, this will come at the cost of requiring a tox
configuration change, and the implementation of the
tests/tests-repo-clone.sh and run_tests.sh scripts
across all repositories.

Change-Id: I23d1d77baa852c73c87c1f2ae29b2ba73c5bc34b
Depends-On: Ia806f19e00703c53f03a2420dbac1da4ba68db6c

commit_message:
Used cached git sources and enable depends-on

Many, many patches have gone into the master branch to
enable the use of depends-on for role tests and to make
use of the git clones put into place by zuul. This patch
ensures that this functionality is now available for this
branch too.

The primary benefit for doing this would be to make use
of the cached git clones provided by zuul to improve test
reliability.

The secondary benefit would be to have the ability to
use depends-on to test patches together.

However, this will come at the cost of requiring a tox
configuration change, and the implementation of the
tests/tests-repo-clone.sh and run_tests.sh scripts
across all repositories.

Change-Id: I23d1d77baa852c73c87c1f2ae29b2ba73c5bc34b
Depends-On: I2abda86df19980c963e3cb176db2f877ba9a312b

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-24 20:47:20.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup voting entries in projects.yaml

Add a new test that checks for non-voting jobs in pipelines and informs
the user about it.

The report currently is:
Checking voting status of jobs
==============================
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/designate
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/manila
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/murano-dashboard
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in gate:
    project: openstack/python-keystoneclient
    job: legacy-keystoneclient-dsvm-functional
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/python-muranoclient
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/sahara-tests

commit_message:
Cleanup voting entries in projects.yaml

Add a new test that checks for non-voting jobs in pipelines and informs
the user about it.

The report currently is:
Checking voting status of jobs
==============================
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/designate
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/manila
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/murano-dashboard
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in gate:
    project: openstack/python-keystoneclient
    job: legacy-keystoneclient-dsvm-functional
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/python-muranoclient
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  Found non-voting job in post:
    project: openstack/sahara-tests
    job: openstack-tox-cover
  (omitting one periodic job)

fix this:
* Remove the non-voting attribute from all post and periodic jobs.
* Remove non-voting job legacy-keystoneclient-dsvm-functional from gate
  pipeline.

Change-Id: I41a44902ca2f7bca1e32692efbb29d2884632ef1

commit_message:
Improve gate post jobs

- Reuse build jobs to publish images
- Add binary jobs in periodic pipeline
- Push all image to dockerhub
- Use branch name for image tag

Change-Id: I53ad3a9c50071a34286f2351f5f245f272c07638

commit_message:
Remove selfcheck.json

The file selfcheck.json has no discernable purpose,
so it is removed. The file pip-selfcheck.json is
automatically created by pip and used to track
when last it checked if it's on the latest version.

The tags implemented in the role are also corrected
to ensure that the placement of the pip.conf file
is considered a 'config' task, not an 'install'
task. The sub-tags are removed as they are unnecessary.

Change-Id: I53ad3a9c50071a34286f2351f5f245f272c07638

commit_message:
Always generate ARA subunit results

We'd like to see our tests results show up in OpenStack Health
regardless of whether the test passed or failed. This patch
makes sure that it will always try to generate them.

It also implements a routine to try and find where ARA is
installed, because it's not always in a tox venv called
'functional' which was the previously hard-coded location.

Change-Id: I3d967567af9d9c9583f34c89789a38e60717781e

commit_message:
Create cluster without using a failed task

Currently a new cluster is created by using a try/rescue
operation which always fails for a new cluster, causing
a lot of confusion due to the failed task report.

This patch implements an improvement which tests the
cluster state and creates a new one if it is not ready
without requiring the task to fail.

As the cluster creation is a single task, it's merged
into the rabbitmq_cluster.yml task file.

As the tags are all the same, the tag is set in the
main task file instead of individually on all the tasks.

Change-Id: Iaa8e429cbd1c539d8242453c0490373c758dd9fe

commit_message:
Check and set cookie without using a failed task

Currently the checking of the cookie content uses
a try/rescue block and for a new install always
results in a failed task. This causes a lot of
confusion due to the failed task report.

This patch improves the process by executing the
stop/start if the cookie file is changed in any
way by the copy task. This is far simpler and
results in no task fails.

As all the tasks related to this were marked
rabbitmq-config the tag implementation is set
in the main tasks file and removed from all the
individual tasks.

Change-Id: Iba959f730f2453bf9a295158749b96ed3a966ef4

commit_message:
Resolve ansible-lint test failures

With the merge of https://review.openstack.org/520177 in the
tests repo some ansible-lint failures which previously were
not being picked up are now detected.

This adds the appropriate skip tags to the tasks so that they
are not evaluated by ansible-lint.

Change-Id: Ia91f73d4f17e94a150c93c75c618778c25823d0d

subject: EPEL wrapper
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4264, 'name': 'Matthias Runge', 'email': 'mrunge@redhat.com', 'username': 'mrunge'}, {'_account_id': 6796, 'name': 'Giulio Fidente', 'email': 'gfidente@redhat.com', 'username': 'gfidente'}, {'_account_id': 8297, 'name': 'Sofer Athlan-Guyot', 'email': 'sathlang@redhat.com', 'username': 'chem'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22954, 'name': 'Juan Badia Payno', 'email': 'jbadiapa@redhat.com', 'username': 'jbadiapa'}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26828, 'name': 'cjeanneret - deactivated', 'email': 'cedric.jeanneret@camptocamp.com', 'username': 'Tengu'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 06:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 07:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 07:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 08:19:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 09:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:22:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thank you for your work here! I've seen quite a few breakages caused by changes in EPEL.

For RDO based installs, there is the CentOS opstools SIG, which provides builds for collectd, provifing more collectd features than in EPEL provided builds. The same is true for CentOS directly. I would prefer to disable EPEL completely, or at least not to pull collectd from there.

In Kolla, EPEL is disabled for the collectd container: https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/master/docker/collectd/Dockerfile.j2#L31

yum install centos-release-opstools will add and enable the corresponding repository."}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:23:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hello Matthias. As far as I know, puppet modules for collectd want to pull it from EPEL, because it's more up-to-date than standard rhl repositories, and it provides more modules (if you check the puppet-collectd being pulled in I0576df2902cc44e7e9ff312214d609095132f2a4, epel is really needed only for a few subset of modules I'm not even sure are used in the whole tripleo project).

If I understand you, you'd rather want me to set the "epel_enabled" to "false" by default, right? I'm not against it, as long as we still get the possibility to activate it easily (which should be OK using hiera).'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2017-11-24 10:49:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Cédric, thank you.

Ideally, we could go without EPEL enabled at all. I agree, that might not be possible.

Regarding more up-to date or not, centos-opstools has collectd 5.7.2, collectd-5.8 in -testing, where EPEL has 5.7.1.

Leaving that aside, I'm also concerned about enabling both (e.g. for providing fluentd): if both are enabled, the latest rpm is being pulled. If versions are equal, results may be quite unexpected: collectd pulled from epel, collectd plugin foo pulled from centos (or else) might or might not work and might be hard to debug."}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 11:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

No problem, latest patch sets the "epel_enabled" to false by default (and correct the unit test accordingly). Let users decide for themselves if they want to risk any breakage.

I also let the "security net" with the includepkgs param - one *should* use it in order to ensure packages come from the source s/he wants.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2017-11-24 12:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Just chatting about possible options.  I thing that the class interface with the $epel_includepkgs may lead to errors later on.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 12:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 12:49:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2017-11-24 14:20:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(3 comments)

Won't block on this, but I would really like to have the inline template removed unless there is a serious need to keep it (like not depending on stdlib)"}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 14:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 14:44:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

:) inline_template replaced, and I took the opportunity to sort the package list - that way, well, it's better.

I think we're pretty good, aren't we?"}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-24 14:44:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 22954, 'date': '2017-11-25 08:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2017-11-27 09:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I think the wrapper is good but we don't want to use EPEL ever, if we enable it then that is probably a mistake"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2017-11-27 09:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-27 09:53:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

some modules seem to come from EPEL, like rabbitmq - not sure that one is used though (it should imho). Using this wrapper would also prevent possible issues if people activate epel from some other heat template without giving attention to the consequences (broken packages and so on).
Last argument in favor: certbot and its dependencies come from epel, and that can be used in order to get Let's Encrypt certificate for the public endpoint. I'm currently preparing some script/project that will allow to manage LE certificate across multiple controllers, but that will need EPEL due to the deps on certbot :)."}, {'account_id': 26828, 'date': '2017-11-28 08:08:17.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

For now we can work around the EPEL requirement in puppet-collectd, let's avoid any bad behavior."}]

commit_message:
EPEL wrapper

This new class will prevent any package breakage due to version
mismatch. Activating blindly EPEL is a bad idea, packages should be
filtered in order to avoid any issue.
Of course, EPEL module has been added to the Puppetfile_extras.

This wrapper was mainly for "collectd" related stuff, and is also
included in the tripleo::profile::base::metrics::collectd.

Change-Id: I7ee47566912cf4fb42c086ff35e95caf68cc988e

[{'created': '2017-11-27 12:15:34.000000000', 'message': "Change plan files whitelist when creating plan

This change removes files whitelisting when creating/updating plan
using 'Local Folder' option to avoid problems with missing files
in case a new file with non listed extension is added to
tripleo-heat-templates. Instead, we're blacklisting a set of filepaths
which we're sure we can omit from deployment plan.

Closes-Bug: 1734676
Change-Id: Ie0cc450dcad2ec2cae7c15daffe362dfca255f6f
"}]
commit_message:
Change plan files whitelist when creating plan

This change removes files whitelisting when creating/updating plan
using 'Local Folder' option to avoid problems with missing files
in case a new file with non listed extension is added to
tripleo-heat-templates. Instead, we're blacklisting a set of filepaths
which we're sure we can omit from deployment plan.

Closes-Bug: 1734676
Change-Id: Ie0cc450dcad2ec2cae7c15daffe362dfca255f6f

subject: Use EPEL for debootstrap on centos
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4146, 'name': 'Clark Boylan', 'email': 'cboylan@sapwetik.org', 'username': 'cboylan'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23317, 'name': 'ShangXiao', 'email': 'shangxiaobj@inspur.com', 'username': 'ShangXiao'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6039, 'date': '2017-11-28 00:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-28 00:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-28 01:36:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think it's going to be a problem that we conflate yum with dnf based systems like fedora, which don't have the epel repo.

i'm not defending this script, btw :)"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-28 04:20:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

ok, no wonder i'm so confused

debootstrap was coming from 

  2017-11-23 02:55:35.825989 | primary |  debootstrap       noarch 1.0.81-1.el7             centos-openstack-ocata  72 k

indeed we started failing

 2017-11-28 00:30:19.237468 | primary | + sudo yum -y install bzip2 dpkg debootstrap docker kpartx util-linux qemu-img policycoreutils-python
 2017-11-28 00:30:19.369523 | primary | Loaded plugins: fastestmirror
 2017-11-28 00:30:19.420831 | primary | Loading mirror speeds from cached hostfile
 2017-11-28 00:30:19.571794 | primary | No package dpkg available.
 2017-11-28 00:30:19.624851 | primary | No package debootstrap available.

(we should have bailed at this point, see the magic we do in devstack to pickup yum failures.  anyway)

with this, as described, we get it from epel

 2017-11-28 01:04:13.605204 | primary |  debootstrap             noarch 1.0.87-1.el7                      epel     76 k
 2017-11-28 01:04:13.605248 | primary |  docker                  x86_64 2:1.12.6-61.git85d7426.el7.centos extras   15 M
 2017-11-28 01:04:13.605293 | primary |  dpkg                    x86_64 1.17.27-1.el7                     epel    1.3 M

what's interesting is that we've never had dpkg and everything works on centos, see [1] -- we've just never noticed before.  so the problem isn't actually a lack of dpkg, even though that is a problem.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/34/522134/1/check/dib-dsvm-functests-python2-centos-7/7e8f638/job-output.txt.gz"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-28 04:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-28 04:31:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

i just updated the commit message to reflect that it's really debootstrap missing, and dpkg is a side-effect (but still wrong)

approving this to get gate going (insert grumble should be using bindep something something)"}, {'account_id': 23317, 'date': '2017-11-28 04:57:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-28 00:20:57.000000000', 'message': "Install dpkg on yum-based systems in testing

The dib-dsvm-functests-python2-centos-7 job is failing because the
debootstrap element can't find any dpkg executable. Make sure it is
installed on yum-based systems.

Change-Id: I1e9db5130a05a004c3c877d1444d7097023c06e2
"}, {'created': '2017-11-28 00:50:42.000000000', 'message': "Install dpkg on yum-based systems in testing

The dib-dsvm-functests-python2-centos-7 job is failing because the
debootstrap element can't find any dpkg executable. Make sure it is
installed on yum-based systems. To do this we explicitly list dpkg as a
dependency and enable epel when installing it as that is the repo where
it can be found.

Change-Id: I1e9db5130a05a004c3c877d1444d7097023c06e2
"}, {'created': '2017-11-28 04:26:56.000000000', 'message': "Use EPEL for debootstrap on centos

I747c2b8754effbc6ec82af3bf7543fd9599a6c14 removed the
centos-openstack-octata repos from the base image.  We were previously
getting debootstrap from there, so this broke the centos-7 based jobs.
Enable EPEL for the install so we use that version of debootstrap.

Additionally we noticed that dpkg wasn't installed on the build host
either, but is actually required (calls were silently failing ... a
problem for another day).  Add this.

Change-Id: I1e9db5130a05a004c3c877d1444d7097023c06e2
"}]
commit_message:
Use EPEL for debootstrap on centos

I747c2b8754effbc6ec82af3bf7543fd9599a6c14 removed the
centos-openstack-octata repos from the base image.  We were previously
getting debootstrap from there, so this broke the centos-7 based jobs.
Enable EPEL for the install so we use that version of debootstrap.

Additionally we noticed that dpkg wasn't installed on the build host
either, but is actually required (calls were silently failing ... a
problem for another day).  Add this.

Change-Id: I1e9db5130a05a004c3c877d1444d7097023c06e2

commit_message:
Skip tempest test test_implied_roles_create_check_show_delete

This test has been included in tempest-16.1.0 which has been
promoted in ocata repository.

According to the information in [1], this issue will be fixed
by a new version of mod_wsgi in CentOS, but it will take some
time to land.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478168

Change-Id: Ifc5f30bd9d3de7d967eeafb5f0ff9a017605ce2a

commit_message:
Propose specification to include policy scope

This specification details the benefits of including scope in policy
operations.

Change-Id: I36847d9dbeb78aa5b8feff0692ba81847c6f9f6a

[{'account_id': 26133, 'date': '2017-10-16 07:02:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2017-10-16 07:02:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 12076, 'date': '2017-10-16 11:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[{'created': '2017-10-16 07:02:23.000000000', 'message': 'The realization of the qos service and test cases

Change-Id: Ifbf453b57f7e18919318e1dae2ca2849e149a29b
Signed-off-by: xiaohan zhang <zhangxiaohan@szzt.com.cn>
'}, {'created': '2017-10-18 02:45:32.000000000', 'message': "QoS implementation(Part1: Qos Plugin)

1. What is the problem?
Tricircle now don't support QoS service, we should add QoS
servicesupporting.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
We implement Tricircle QoS service by inherit neutron QoS plugin.
For QoS automation deployment in local, we should implement QoS xjob
jobs.

Change-Id: Ifbf453b57f7e18919318e1dae2ca2849e149a29b
Signed-off-by: xiaohan zhang <zhangxiaohan@szzt.com.cn>

For QoS automation deployment in local, we should implement QoS xjob
jobs.

commit_message:
QoS implementation(Part1: Qos Plugin)

1. What is the problem?
Tricircle now don't support QoS service, we should add QoS
servicesupporting.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
We implement Tricircle QoS service by inherit neutron QoS plugin.
For QoS automation deployment in local, we should implement QoS xjob
jobs.

Change-Id: Ifbf453b57f7e18919318e1dae2ca2849e149a29b
Signed-off-by: xiaohan zhang <zhangxiaohan@szzt.com.cn>

commit_message:
Add the verify of network_id in _test_create_interface_by_port_id

When create interface by port_id,
not only iface['port_id'] is equal to port_id,
but also iface['net_id'] should be same with network_id.

I think only check iface['port_id'] is not enough.

Change-Id: I82b53a996e8a3c1945fd16a7cf10ee85850be60d
