revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 20:27:54.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Alternate fix for validating image on rebuild

Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446
'}, {'created': '2017-11-17 21:10:36.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Alternate fix for validating image on rebuild

Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446
'}, {'created': '2017-11-17 22:06:56.000000000', 'message': "Alternate fix for validating image on rebuild

This aims to fix the issue described in bug 1664931 where a rebuild
fails to validate the existing host with the scheduler when a new
image is provided. The previous attempt to do this could cause rebuilds
to fail unnecessarily because we ran _all_ of the filters during a
rebuild, which could cause usage/resource filters to prevent an otherwise
valid rebuild from succeeding.

This aims to classify filters as either policy-only or not, and only apply
the former during a rebuild scheduler check. We do this by using the
same_host scheduler hint, set to our own uuid. This should (a) filter out
all hosts other than the one we're running on and (b) be detectable by
the filtering infrastructure as an internally-generated scheduling request
in order to trigger the policy-only filtering behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1664931
Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446
"}, {'created': '2017-11-20 20:01:17.000000000', 'message': "Alternate fix for validating image on rebuild

This aims to fix the issue described in bug 1664931 where a rebuild
fails to validate the existing host with the scheduler when a new
image is provided. The previous attempt to do this could cause rebuilds
to fail unnecessarily because we ran _all_ of the filters during a
rebuild, which could cause usage/resource filters to prevent an otherwise
valid rebuild from succeeding.

This aims to classify filters as either policy-only or not, and only apply
the former during a rebuild scheduler check. We do this by using the
same_host scheduler hint, set to our own uuid. This should (a) filter out
all hosts other than the one we're running on and (b) be detectable by
the filtering infrastructure as an internally-generated scheduling request
in order to trigger the policy-only filtering behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1664931
Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446
"}, {'created': '2017-11-21 14:51:52.000000000', 'message': "Alternate fix for validating image on rebuild

This aims to fix the issue described in bug 1664931 where a rebuild
fails to validate the existing host with the scheduler when a new
image is provided. The previous attempt to do this could cause rebuilds
to fail unnecessarily because we ran _all_ of the filters during a
rebuild, which could cause usage/resource filters to prevent an otherwise
valid rebuild from succeeding.

This aims to classify filters as either policy-only or not, and only apply
the former during a rebuild scheduler check. We do this by using an internal
scheduler hint, indicating a policy check. This should (a) filter out
all hosts other than the one we're running on and (b) be detectable by
the filtering infrastructure as an internally-generated scheduling request

Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446

image is provided. The previous attempt to do this could cause rebuilds

This aims to classify filters as useful for rebuild or not, and only apply

all hosts other than the one we're running on and (b) be detectable by
the filtering infrastructure as an internally-generated scheduling request
in order to trigger the correct filtering behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1664931
Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446
"}]
commit_message:
Refined fix for validating image on rebuild

This aims to fix the issue described in bug 1664931 where a rebuild
fails to validate the existing host with the scheduler when a new
image is provided. The previous attempt to do this could cause rebuilds
to fail unnecessarily because we ran _all_ of the filters during a
rebuild, which could cause usage/resource filters to prevent an otherwise
valid rebuild from succeeding.

This aims to classify filters as useful for rebuild or not, and only apply
the former during a rebuild scheduler check. We do this by using an internal
scheduler hint, indicating our intent. This should (a) filter out
all hosts other than the one we're running on and (b) be detectable by
the filtering infrastructure as an internally-generated scheduling request
in order to trigger the correct filtering behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1664931
Change-Id: I1a46ef1503be2febcd20f4594f44344d05525446

commit_message:
ceilometer: set event dispatcher to Gnocchi by default

The current default of database does not make Gnocchi work completely, as the
Gnocchi dispatcher does not receive the events from Ceilometer.

This is a very partial cherry-pick of a2e0aa4d1c22737511b485b5112d25c84d29d6df
which exposed CeilometerEventDispatcher when Panko was added.

Change-Id: Ibcad7db2a0a06bd7d4ee8843ab5e82ffeb3cd987

commit_message:
Fix config race condition importing remote clients

When setting remote_(nova|cinder|neutron)_client config options
for use with single tenant mode, the code to initialise the class
is run before the config is initialised (for the task manager only)

The result of this is that the task manager always gets the default
setting and the remote nova/cinder/neutron clients get instantiated
from the wrong class and resources don't get created in the single
tenant as desired.

This traceback shows that we only see imports all the way down to
remote.py where the class the config option is read, and the config
hasn't been initialised yet:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/trove-taskmanager", line 6, in <module>
    from trove.cmd.taskmanager import main
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/cmd/taskmanager.py", line 18, in <module>
    from trove.taskmanager import api as task_api
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/taskmanager/api.py", line 29, in <module>
    from trove.guestagent import models as agent_models
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/guestagent/models.py", line 25, in <module>
    from trove.db import models as dbmodels
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/db/models.py", line 20, in <module>
    from trove.common import models
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/common/models.py", line 22, in <module>
    from trove.common import remote
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/common/remote.py", line 195, in <module>
    raise Exception(CONF.remote_nova_client)
Exception: trove.common.remote.nova_client <----- fail

After this fix:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/trove-taskmanager", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/cmd/common.py", line 62, in run
    conf = initialize(**kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/cmd/common.py", line 50, in initialize
    get_db_api().configure_db(conf)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/db/sqlalchemy/api.py", line 85, in configure_db
    session.configure_db(options)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/db/sqlalchemy/session.py", line 41, in configure_db
    from trove.backup import models as backup_models
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/backup/models.py", line 25, in <module>
    from trove.common.remote import create_swift_client
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/trove/common/remote.py", line 195, in <module>
    raise Exception(CONF.remote_nova_client)
Exception: trove.common.single_tenant_remote.nova_client_trove_admin <----- good

Change-Id: Ia869e466a70d72d727176adc3692c1f69863959f

commit_message:
tox: allow to specify module when running pep8 env

The horizon repo now contains three python modules: openstack_auth,
horizon and openstack_dashboard. It is useful if we can specify
a specific python module when running 'tox -e pep8'.

Change-Id: I35d0f2a762806c52bd2fa0e863db500b4ae2c605

[{'created': '2017-11-17 11:49:28.000000000', 'message': 'Get all needed instances for volumes attachments at Admin->Volumes

Nova server_list() wrapper needs to receive an explicit `all_tenants`
boolean flag in order to request instances for _all_ tenants -
otherwise while rendering Admin->Volumes table Django will request
missing instances (to get their names for volume attachments) one by
one, thus significantly increasing response time.

This patch adds check if all_tenants in search_opts and add it to
the search else uses tenant_id in the search_opts.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Sutyagin <dsutyagin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ivan Kolodyazhny <e0ne@e0ne.info>
Change-Id: I4761d7da15036b69619649871aef91e1799ee385
Closes-Bug: #1508568
(cherry picked from commit 3a99499ba0adafd1e64262a5ba63ae94b1f05cf0)
'}]
commit_message:
Get all needed instances for volumes attachments at Admin->Volumes

Nova server_list() wrapper needs to receive an explicit `all_tenants`
boolean flag in order to request instances for _all_ tenants -
otherwise while rendering Admin->Volumes table Django will request
missing instances (to get their names for volume attachments) one by
one, thus significantly increasing response time.

This patch adds check if all_tenants in search_opts and add it to
the search else uses tenant_id in the search_opts.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Sutyagin <dsutyagin@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ivan Kolodyazhny <e0ne@e0ne.info>
Change-Id: I4761d7da15036b69619649871aef91e1799ee385
Closes-Bug: #1508568
(cherry picked from commit 3a99499ba0adafd1e64262a5ba63ae94b1f05cf0)

commit_message:
Do not set dhcp_domain in Nova from overcloud_domain_name

The dhcp_domain option was deprecated in Pike [1] and is causing
issues like [2] by configuring the shortname of nodes to their
fully qualified domain name.

1. https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/pike/nova/conf/network.py#L468
2. https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1507888

Closes-Bug: 1733874
Change-Id: I4db66155b2c4ba8e0639ec00f938a8bc2ac85762

messages:
[{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-11-16 19:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9625, 'date': '2017-11-27 19:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2017-11-28 02:34:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

OK. I compared with the release note docs between [1] and the master (newest).
It seems like this patch can remove the version expression at the index so i can see "Swift Client Release Notes 3.4.1" in the master but "Swift Client Release Notes" with this. it seems good to land this as it is because 3.4.1 is not yet released (in dev version) to avoid confusion for users.

I'm also wondering why "the current (unreleased) version" can refer the Pike release which has been released already but it should be far from this patch's intension so we can land this as it is.  

1: http://logs.openstack.org/38/520738/1/check/build-openstack-releasenotes/44a0d45/html/current.html'}, {'account_id': 25695, 'date': '2017-11-28 03:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}]

commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I623fe918c1e4ddafa93efc91ed550a365cec1cf0

I checked below code: auth_plugin.py. You may see it.
==========================
# Copyright 2014 Rackspace
# Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation
# Copyright 2013 Spanish National Research Council.
# All Rights Reserved.

#    Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may
#    not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain
#    a copy of the License at
#
#         http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
#
#    Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
#    distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT
#    WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the
#    License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations
#    under the License.

import logging

import pkg_resources
import six

from troveclient._i18n import _
from troveclient import exceptions


logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


_discovered_plugins = {}


def discover_auth_systems():
    """Discover the available auth-systems.

    This won't take into account the old style auth-systems.
    """
    ep_name = 'openstack.client.auth_plugin'
    for ep in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points(ep_name):
        try:
            auth_plugin = ep.load()
        except (ImportError, pkg_resources.UnknownExtra, AttributeError) as e:
            logger.debug(_("ERROR: Cannot load auth plugin %s") % ep.name)
            logger.debug(e, exc_info=1)
        else:
            _discovered_plugins[ep.name] = auth_plugin


def load_auth_system_opts(parser):
    """Load options needed by the available auth-systems into a parser.

    This function will try to populate the parser with options from the
    available plugins.
    """
    for name, auth_plugin in six.iteritems(_discovered_plugins):
        add_opts_fn = getattr(auth_plugin, "add_opts", None)
        if add_opts_fn:
            group = parser.add_argument_group("Auth-system '%s' options" %
                                              name)
            add_opts_fn(group)


def load_plugin(auth_system):
    if auth_system in _discovered_plugins:
        return _discovered_plugins[auth_system]()

    raise exceptions.AuthSystemNotFound(auth_system)


class BaseAuthPlugin(object):
    """Base class for authentication plugins.

    An authentication plugin needs to override at least the authenticate
    method to be a valid plugin.
    """
    def __init__(self):
        self.opts = {}

    def get_auth_url(self):
        """Return the auth url for the plugin (if any)."""
        return None

    @staticmethod
    def add_opts(parser):
        """Populate and return the parser with the options for this plugin.

        If the plugin does not need any options, it should return the same
        parser untouched.
        """
        return parser

    def parse_opts(self, args):
        """Parse the actual auth-system options if any.

        This method is expected to populate the attribute self.opts with a
        dict containing the options and values needed to make authentication.
        If the dict is empty, the client should assume that it needs the same
        options as the 'keystone' auth system (i.e. os_username and
        os_password).

        Returns the self.opts dict.
        """
        return self.opts

    def authenticate(self, cls, auth_url):
        """Authenticate using plugin defined method."""
        raise exceptions.AuthSystemNotFound(self.auth_system)'}, {'account_id': 25456, 'date': '2017-07-18 14:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Removed the following votes:

commit_message:
Remove log translations

    Log messages are no longer being translated.
    This removes all use of the _LE, _LI, and _LW
    translation markers to simplify logging and to
    avoid confusion with new contributions.

    See:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: Iee792d0e3bae6a3ea84a3eed2853017c7ec39c76

commit_message:
don't convert generator to list unless required

there's only one scenario where the generator actually needs to be
forced into a list. don't waste time doing something unnecessary.

Change-Id: Iec897b1f6fed3d88b798eb673779e7c68ff930ec

messages: [{'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-23 15:47:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-23 16:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-23 18:12:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-23 18:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2017-11-28 01:57:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-23 15:47:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add hacking to enforce the config fixture

There was an agreement made on the networking-odl meeting [1] not to use
`set_override` on tests but instead use `config` provided by the
oslo_config fixture.

This patch adds a hacking rule to enforce this usage.

[1]:
https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-neutron/2017/neutron_northbound/opendaylight-neutron-neutron_northbound.2017-10-30-15.02.html

Change-Id: Iff2ba69b420cab5473f34a080be029e0a23bb553
'}, {'created': '2017-11-23 16:41:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add hacking to enforce the config fixture

There was an agreement made on the networking-odl meeting [1] not to use
`set_override` on tests but instead use `config` provided by the
oslo_config fixture.

This patch adds a hacking rule to enforce this usage.

[1]:

commit_message:
Add hacking to enforce the config fixture

There was an agreement made on the networking-odl meeting [1] not to use
`set_override` on tests but instead use `config` provided by the
oslo_config fixture.

This patch adds a hacking rule to enforce this usage.

[1]:
https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-neutron/2017/neutron_northbound/opendaylight-neutron-neutron_northbound.2017-10-30-15.02.html

Change-Id: Iff2ba69b420cab5473f34a080be029e0a23bb553

commit_message:
Override settings with a config fixture

There was an agreement made on the networking-odl meeting [1] not to
use `set_override` on tests but instead use `config` provided by the
oslo_config fixture.

This patch modifies tests to use the `oslo_config` fixture whenever
there is a need to overide a setting.

[1]: https://meetings.opendaylight.org/opendaylight-neutron/2017/neutron_northbound/opendaylight-neutron-neutron_northbound.2017-10-30-15.02.html

Change-Id: I9142cd28df74edaa26665e6dae91956e009d7f65

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 8623, 'name': 'Kaitlin Farr', 'email': 'kaitlin.farr@jhuapl.edu', 'username': 'kaitlin.farr'}, {'_account_id': 9914, 'name': 'Ade Lee', 'email': 'alee@redhat.com', 'username': 'alee'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 11561, 'name': 'Dave McCowan', 'email': 'dmccowan@cisco.com', 'username': 'dave-mccowan'}, {'_account_id': 21129, 'name': 'Alan Bishop', 'email': 'abishop@redhat.com', 'username': 'ASBishop'}, {'_account_id': 21797, 'name': 'liujiong', 'display_name': 'Jeremy Liu', 'email': 'liuj285@chinaunicom.cn', 'username': 'liujiong'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-10-24 16:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-10-24 17:24:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8623, 'date': '2017-10-27 21:59:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just to summarize and put all of our conversations in one place:

Etherpad Script
===============

I had written up instructions about how a cloud admin might migrate the key manually and replace the key ID in the database here [1] 


Thanks for the comments, it raised some things that I hadn't thought of, such as how the key is deleted when the volume is deleted. At first, I thought it would be fine to just create different instances of key as the admin on behalf of the user, one for each volume, with the same fixed_key bytes, but then I realized that the user would need to have the admin role to delete the secret. A user with the "creator" role can delete the secrets they create, but not a secret they have only read-access to. I saw the conversation on IRC about this [2], so it seems like you reached the same conclusion.  If we were to continue with this script route with no code changes to Barbican, a user (a service user or a regular user) would need to have the "admin" role to delete the secret, which I don't think would go over well, as you said.

Otherwise, we could implement delete access for ACLs, but I'm not sure if anyone has the time to sign up for that feature?

This route seems kind of like a dead-end to me at the moment, until the issues with creating a secret on behalf of another user are worked out.

Migration key manager in Castellan (this patch)
===============================================

Overall, I like this approach better than moving ConfKeyManager to Castellan, but I am not clear on the path for how the new Barbican key id would replace the one stored in the volume metadata. If this were the only patch merged, a user with a volume encrypted with the fixed key could attach and detach their volume, and it would store the fixed_key in barbican just fine each time, but the key would not get re-used.

This is my understanding of how it would work now:

1. User has a volume that was created with the fixed_key.
2. User attaches the volume to a server
   * Nova calls migration_key_manager.get(000-000..)
   * migration_key_manager returns key data that is now stored in barbican
3. User detaches the volume and attaches again
   * steps from above are repeated, the UUID from the key created in 2 was not stored anywhere?
4. User detaches the volume and deletes it
   * Cinder calls migration_key_manager.delete(000-000..) (does nothing, key uuids created in 2 and 3 were not stored anywhere, so the keys are just hanging out.

Looking back at the cinder spec, it looks like there were two options proposed:

1. Cinder migration thread (still has the issue of creating a key on behalf of another user)
2. From the alternatives section, each piece of code that fetches and stores a key could handle the migration itself.

I can see a third possibility (and maybe this was were you were going with this patch, you just didn't mention it in the commit message), is that there would be some logic added to cinder/nova so that each time the key_manager.get call is invoked and the uuid requested is not the same as the one that was returned (ID was just added to castellan objects [3]), the volume_metadata is updated. Not sure if nova can update cinder metadata??? Nova is the one usually retrieving the keys. But I like this idea.

Sorry for the novel, hope it is understandable.

1. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/migrate-from-fixed-key-to-barbican
2. http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-barbican/%23openstack-barbican.2017-10-23.log.html
3. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/498829/'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-10-30 14:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Just to summarize and put all of our conversations in one place:

Thank you for consolidating things here. Gerrit may not be the perfect
tool for this, but hey, it works.

After some responses in-line, I add a fresh summary at the end.

 > Etherpad Script
 > ===============
 > 
 > I had written up instructions about how a cloud admin might migrate
 > the key manually and replace the key ID in the database here [1]
 > 
 > 
 > Thanks for the comments, it raised some things that I hadn't
 > thought of, such as how the key is deleted when the volume is
 > deleted. At first, I thought it would be fine to just create
 > different instances of key as the admin on behalf of the user, one
 > for each volume, with the same fixed_key bytes, but then I realized
 > that the user would need to have the admin role to delete the
 > secret. A user with the "creator" role can delete the secrets they
 > create, but not a secret they have only read-access to. I saw the
 > conversation on IRC about this [2], so it seems like you reached
 > the same conclusion.  If we were to continue with this script route
 > with no code changes to Barbican, a user (a service user or a
 > regular user) would need to have the "admin" role to delete the
 > secret, which I don't think would go over well, as you said.

I'd state this issue even more strongly. Cinder allows non-admins to
create and delete volumes. If a user's key is migrated in such a way
that the user is not able to delete the migrated key, then either the
key will "leak" (when the volume is deleted but the key is not deleted)
or the cinder code will need to block the user from deleting their own
volume because the key cannot be deleted. I view both of these as no-go.

 > Otherwise, we could implement delete access for ACLs, but I'm not
 > sure if anyone has the time to sign up for that feature?

The more I consider the situation the more I'm convinced delete ACLs are
necessary. Without knowing the scope of the work, I volunteer to help.

 > This route seems kind of like a dead-end to me at the moment, until
 > the issues with creating a secret on behalf of another user are
 > worked out.
 > 
 > Migration key manager in Castellan (this patch)
 > ===============================================
 > 
 > Overall, I like this approach better than moving ConfKeyManager to
 > Castellan, but I am not clear on the path for how the new Barbican
 > key id would replace the one stored in the volume metadata. If this
 > were the only patch merged, a user with a volume encrypted with the
 > fixed key could attach and detach their volume, and it would store
 > the fixed_key in barbican just fine each time, but the key would
 > not get re-used.

I'm wouldn't go so far as saying the fixed key is "stored" in Barbican.
This patch may make it seem that way, in that it returns a valid secret
for the all-zeros key ID, but no such secret will actually be stored
in the Barbican DB.

 > This is my understanding of how it would work now:
 > 
 > 1. User has a volume that was created with the fixed_key.
 > 2. User attaches the volume to a server
 > * Nova calls migration_key_manager.get(000-000..)
 > * migration_key_manager returns key data that is now stored in
 > barbican

Per my comment above, the secret associated with the all-zeros key ID
isn't actually stored in Barbican.

 > 3. User detaches the volume and attaches again
 > * steps from above are repeated, the UUID from the key created in 2
 > was not stored anywhere?

Correct. This patch does not actually create a Barbican key. It just
mimics the behavior _as if_ such an all-zeros key ID existed.

 > 4. User detaches the volume and deletes it
 > * Cinder calls migration_key_manager.delete(000-000..) (does
 > nothing, key uuids created in 2 and 3 were not stored anywhere, so
 > the keys are just hanging out.

I'm not sure what you mean by the keys "hanging out." Just to restate,
no new key IDs are created. The only item in question is the all-zeros
key ID, and it's not actually stored in Barbican.

 > Looking back at the cinder spec, it looks like there were two
 > options proposed:
 > 
 > 1. Cinder migration thread (still has the issue of creating a key
 > on behalf of another user)
 > 2. From the alternatives section, each piece of code that fetches
 > and stores a key could handle the migration itself.
 > 
 > I can see a third possibility (and maybe this was were you were
 > going with this patch, you just didn't mention it in the commit
 > message), is that there would be some logic added to cinder/nova so
 > that each time the key_manager.get call is invoked and the uuid
 > requested is not the same as the one that was returned (ID was just
 > added to castellan objects [3]), the volume_metadata is updated.
 > Not sure if nova can update cinder metadata??? Nova is the one
 > usually retrieving the keys. But I like this idea.
 
Here's my fresh summary. There are three completely independent pieces
required to help users migrate from the ConfKeyManager to Barbican.

1) Provide backward compatibility for the all-zeros key ID during the
migration period (this patch).

2) Replace all instances of the all-zeros key ID in the cinder DB with
actual Barbican key IDs. This is work targeted by your script, but is
also something I plan to do in Cinder itself [4].

3) Enhance the Barbican ACL feature to allow users to delete the
Barbican secret associated with the newly migrated key ID.

Each of these functions autonomously and serves a specific need.

The first piece allows users to switch their key_manager backend to
Barbican without breaking volumes using the all-zeros key ID. All newly
created keys will be stored in Barbican, but the all-zeros key ID
will continue to function.

The second piece cleans things up by effectively purging the all-zeros
key ID from the Cinder DB. After all the all-zeros instances are updated
with Barbican key IDs, the user will be able remove the fixed_key from
Cinder's and Nova's config file.

The third piece is necessary in order for existing volume delete workflows
to function. Users need to retain the ability to delete their own volumes,
and that requires the ability to delete the migrated Barbican key.

Last thing to note is the second item (key migration) cannot take place
without the first (legacy compatibility). The key_manager backend cannot
be switched to Barbican unless the compatibility layer is in place.

This patch provides the legacy compatibility layer.

 > Sorry for the novel, hope it is understandable.

This is good stuff, and we need to continue the discussion. This gerrit
review is as good a place as any!

 > 1. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/migrate-from-fixed-key-to-barbican
 > 2. http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-barbican/%23openstack-barbican.2017-10-23.log.html
 > 3. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/498829/

[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/511900/2'}, {'account_id': 11561, 'date': '2017-11-13 17:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-13 18:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-14 15:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8623, 'date': '2017-11-14 17:38:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks for responding to all my comments.  When I was first reviewing the patch, I thought there was a store() command that was being called in the if-key-uuid-is-all-zeroes statement after the key object was created and returned.  But looking at this patch again, I see I was mistaken, so please ignore my comments about the keys not being deleted.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-14 18:04:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-14 19:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-14 21:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11561, 'date': '2017-11-21 02:39:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-11-21 04:29:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

LGTM, just some nits, see inline comments! And thanks for this patch!'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-21 14:24:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(4 comments)

Thanks for the review, Jeremy!'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2017-11-21 14:24:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2017-11-21 16:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2017-11-21 16:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Has my support will switch to +2 when i see Dave or Kaitlin chime in'}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-11-22 01:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2017-11-27 19:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11561, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11561, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-11-28 01:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21797, 'date': '2017-11-28 02:16:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-24 16:13:42.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Support handling legacy all-zeros key ID

This WIP is meant to solicit community feedback. If the approach is deemed
acceptible, I'll update the patch with unit tests and a new commit message.

This patch addresses a specific use case, where a user has encrypted volumes
based on the fixed_key used by Cinder's and Nova's ConfKeyManager. The user
wishes to switch to Barbican, but existing volumes must continue to function
during the migration period.

The code conditionally adds a shim around the backend KeyManager when both
of these conditions are met:

1) The configuration contains a fixed_key value. This essentially signals
   the ConfKeyManager has been in use at one time
2) The current backend is *not* the ConfKeyManager

When the shim is active, a MigrationKeyManager class is dynamically created
that extends the backend's KeyManager class. The MigrationKeyManager exists
solely to override two functions:

o The KeyManager.get() function detects requests for the secret associated
  with the fixed_key, which is identified by an all-zeros key ID.

  - Requests for the all-zeros key ID are handled by mimicing the
    ConfKeyManager's response, which is a secret derived from the fixed_key.
  - Requests for any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

o The KeyManager.delete() function is similar:

  - Requests to delete the all-zeros key ID are essentially ignored, just as
    is done by the ConfKeyManager.
  - Requests to delete any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

All other KeyManager functions are not overridden, and will therefore be
handled directly by the real backend.

Change-Id: Ia5316490201c33e23a4206838d5a4fb3dd00f527
"}, {'created': '2017-10-24 17:24:23.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Support handling legacy all-zeros key ID

"}, {'created': '2017-11-14 15:13:18.000000000', 'message': "Support handling legacy all-zeros key ID

This patch addresses a specific use case, where a user has encrypted volumes
based on the fixed_key used by Cinder's and Nova's ConfKeyManager. The user
wishes to switch to Barbican, but existing volumes must continue to function
during the migration period.

The code conditionally adds a shim around the backend KeyManager when both
of these conditions are met:

1) The configuration contains a fixed_key value. This essentially signals
   the ConfKeyManager has been in use at one time
2) The current backend is *not* the ConfKeyManager

When the shim is active, a MigrationKeyManager class is dynamically created
that extends the backend's KeyManager class. The MigrationKeyManager exists
solely to override two functions:

o The KeyManager.get() function detects requests for the secret associated
  with the fixed_key, which is identified by an all-zeros key ID.

  - Requests for the all-zeros key ID are handled by mimicing the
    ConfKeyManager's response, which is a secret derived from the fixed_key.
  - Requests for any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

o The KeyManager.delete() function is similar:

  - Requests to delete the all-zeros key ID are essentially ignored, just as
    is done by the ConfKeyManager.
  - Requests to delete any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

All other KeyManager functions are not overridden, and will therefore be
handled directly by the real backend.

SecurityImpact
Change-Id: Ia5316490201c33e23a4206838d5a4fb3dd00f527
"}, {'created': '2017-11-14 18:04:42.000000000', 'message': "Support handling legacy all-zeros key ID

This patch addresses a specific use case, where a user has encrypted volumes
based on the fixed_key used by Cinder's and Nova's ConfKeyManager. The user
wishes to switch to Barbican, but existing volumes must continue to function
during the migration period.

The code conditionally adds a shim around the backend KeyManager when both
of these conditions are met:

1) The configuration contains a fixed_key value. This essentially signals
   the ConfKeyManager has been in use at one time
2) The current backend is *not* the ConfKeyManager

When the shim is active, a MigrationKeyManager class is dynamically created
that extends the backend's KeyManager class. The MigrationKeyManager exists
solely to override two functions:

o The KeyManager.get() function detects requests for the secret associated
  with the fixed_key, which is identified by an all-zeros key ID.

  - Requests for the all-zeros key ID are handled by mimicing the
    ConfKeyManager's response, which is a secret derived from the fixed_key.
  - Requests for any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

o The KeyManager.delete() function is similar:

  - Requests to delete the all-zeros key ID are essentially ignored, just as
    is done by the ConfKeyManager.
  - Requests to delete any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

All other KeyManager functions are not overridden, and will therefore be
handled directly by the real backend.

SecurityImpact
Change-Id: Ia5316490201c33e23a4206838d5a4fb3dd00f527

commit_message:
Support handling legacy all-zeros key ID

This patch addresses a specific use case, where a user has encrypted
volumes based on the fixed_key used by Cinder's and Nova's
ConfKeyManager. The user wishes to switch to Barbican, but existing
volumes must continue to function during the migration period.

The code conditionally adds a shim around the backend KeyManager when
both of these conditions are met:

1) The configuration contains a fixed_key value. This essentially
   signals the ConfKeyManager has been in use at one time
2) The current backend is *not* the ConfKeyManager

When the shim is active, a MigrationKeyManager class is dynamically
created that extends the backend's KeyManager class. The
MigrationKeyManager exists solely to override two functions:

o The KeyManager.get() function detects requests for the secret
  associated with the fixed_key, which is identified by an all-zeros
  key ID.

  - Requests for the all-zeros key ID are handled by mimicing the
    ConfKeyManager's response, which is a secret derived from the
    fixed_key.
  - Requests for any other key ID are passed on to the real backend.

o The KeyManager.delete() function is similar:

  - Requests to delete the all-zeros key ID are essentially ignored,
    just as is done by the ConfKeyManager.
  - Requests to delete any other key ID are passed on to the real
    backend.

All other KeyManager functions are not overridden, and will therefore be
handled directly by the real backend.

SecurityImpact
Change-Id: Ia5316490201c33e23a4206838d5a4fb3dd00f527

subject: Skip test_show_host volume test
messages:
[{'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-11-14 10:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2017-11-17 00:49:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-11-20 00:39:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)

Thanks for the review. If it's not a Cinder bug then I'm OK with removing the test.

For background, the 'admin_only' kwarg was added for identity v2. Downstream we added policy enforcement to it but upstream it only does a context is_admin check. When we upstreamed the tests, we mistakenly forgot that, so I added admin_only as a compromise for not removing those tests since they are a stable API. But anyway, this kwarg can be removed when we remove identity v2 tests from Patrole."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2017-11-20 02:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yea, i talked to Jay over IRC on this and it is found doc is right and policy enforcement is missed in cinder code. i will say we keep the original test with policy but skip with cinder bug. once cinder bug is fixed we remove the skip tag.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-11-22 01:09:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-11-22 01:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Done, also cleaned up commit message which was a little messy'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2017-11-25 16:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

be an admin-only test because Cinder does not do policy enforcement
for this endpoint [0]; instead, it checks whether the request
contest is_admin [1]. The policy in code documentation [0] does not
include the GET endpoint for the "volume_extension:hosts" policy
action.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/10a3f4e1c6f21effc79fd309628111c221543e0d/cinder/policies/hosts.py
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/0cf910d4345c000e8c306b1cb2b2dd291975cf71/cinder/api/contrib/hosts.py#L149

Change-Id: I348166738ae574ebd7220802cfc00f143d52aa2c
'}, {'created': '2017-11-22 01:09:55.000000000', 'message': 'Skip test_show_host volume test

This PS makes test_show_host volume test in test_volume_hosts_rbac
skip until bug 1732808 is resolved. This is because Cinder does
not currently do policy enforcement for this endpoint.

Instead, Cinder checks whether the request context is_admin [1].
The policy in code documentation [0] does not include the "show"
endpoint for the "volume_extension:hosts" policy action
(i.e. GET /hosts/{host_name} is missing).

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/10a3f4e1c6f21effc79fd309628111c221543e0d/cinder/policies/hosts.py
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/0cf910d4345c000e8c306b1cb2b2dd291975cf71/cinder/api/contrib/hosts.py#L149

Related-Bug: #1732808
Change-Id: I348166738ae574ebd7220802cfc00f143d52aa2c
'}]
commit_message:
Skip test_show_host volume test

This PS makes test_show_host volume test in test_volume_hosts_rbac
skip until bug 1732808 is resolved. This is because Cinder does
not currently do policy enforcement for this endpoint.

Instead, Cinder checks whether the request context is_admin [1].
The policy in code documentation [0] does not include the "show"
endpoint for the "volume_extension:hosts" policy action
(i.e. GET /hosts/{host_name} is missing).

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/10a3f4e1c6f21effc79fd309628111c221543e0d/cinder/policies/hosts.py
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/0cf910d4345c000e8c306b1cb2b2dd291975cf71/cinder/api/contrib/hosts.py#L149

Related-Bug: #1732808
Change-Id: I348166738ae574ebd7220802cfc00f143d52aa2c

[{'created': '2017-11-27 11:24:22.000000000', 'message': 'Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: Id412a6b3503e00bd870ccb8f3acc5f3957c23f5d
Closes-Bug: 1734620
'}]
commit_message:
Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: Id412a6b3503e00bd870ccb8f3acc5f3957c23f5d
Closes-Bug: 1734620

[{'created': '2017-06-14 07:52:00.000000000', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid usingg
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

'}, {'created': '2017-11-27 02:24:34.000000000', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

As mentioned in [1], we should avoid usingg six.iteritems to achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items instead, as it will return iterators
in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys will more readable.

In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see the
link [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I620c9cc201c62f033a5467aa52625b56e19933cb
'}, {'created': '2017-11-27 10:50:43.000000000', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems() to achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items() instead, as it will return iterators
in Python 3 as well, and it is more readable.

In Python 2, the overhead of dict.items() creating a new list should be
negligible for most use cases in OpenStack [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I620c9cc201c62f033a5467aa52625b56e19933cb
'}]
commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems() to achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items() instead, as it will return iterators
in Python 3 as well, and it is more readable.

In Python 2, the overhead of dict.items() creating a new list should be
negligible for most use cases in OpenStack [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I620c9cc201c62f033a5467aa52625b56e19933cb

commit_message:
OVB-HA: run when ci/environments/ovb-ha.yaml is touched

ci/environments/ovb-ha.yaml is a new file in THT, where any change on it
will trigger ovb-ha to run.

Depends-On: I58583f1699ce05b428f3b5bfdbc0bc99d1e4eecc
Change-Id: Ie782f73c74f0d939527d055c9f19e3e8850225ce

commit_message:
Versioned notifications for service create and delete

New notifications service.create and service.delete are introduced
with INFO priority and the payload of the notification is the serialized
form of the already existing Service versioned object. Service.create
notification will be emitted after the service is created (so the uuid
is available) and also send the service.delete notification after the
service is deleted.

Implement blueprint: service-create-destroy-notification

Change-Id: I955d98f9fd4b121f98e172e5ab30eb668a24006d

commit_message:
Submit generated template file directly

Redirect from the template generation page to stack list page
 and open stack creation modal directly.
Referenced files of the template will be stored in a hidden
 field as a json string.

Change-Id: I58e2ec4e215670463504305a01ed33a6766067f6

commit_message:
Do not force using the remote "origin" when testing upgrades

Zuul checkout of origin/stable/pike doesn't work, and needs
only stable/pike instead [1].

Change-Id: Ib2bee665e164f02817487c311e125329d54c43d8
(cherry picked from commit ebfd9ab9ae9153f78ccf8084179963922403c3fa)

commit_message:
Clean up zuul files

Changes to legacy-bifrost-jobs.yaml:
- creates two jobs:
  - bifrost-base
  - bifrost-integration
- adds 'irrelevant-files' section to bifrost-base (from project.yaml)
  as well as additional irrelevant files

Changes to project.yaml:
- moves 'irrelevant-files' section to legacy-bifrost-jobs.yaml
- removes branches, since it doesn't apply to master and the stable
  branches have their own versions of zuul files
- removes experimental section (since it was only used for the stable
  branches)
- sorts the jobs list; voting first, alphabetical; non-voting second

Change-Id: I514e7e40ecb95580a47922b253d8046cfcd1634c

commit_message:
Use requests.codes.XX constants instead of hardcoded constants

Some of the code uses code for http error other part uses their
equivalent constant defined in request library. This change bring
consistancy in using http error.

Change-Id: I597e2a937def7d724f1fda2126c336923edd64ee

commit_message:
Revise the implementation in container exec_resize

This patch revises the client to be robust to handle exception from server
when doing exec_resize, and make the outcome to be similar as docker.

Change-Id: Idcef0b7a368db34df3fcd03ef83c1d5bd45aadb7
Closes-Bug: #1732498

commit_message:
Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

Change-Id: I49bb60a05cf63247091ee72591a799f6efc7c84b

'}, {'created': '2017-11-20 02:52:09.000000000', 'message': "Set network mode on creating container

This patch changed the workflow to configure the network in
docker. The old workflow is as following:
* Create container with default network_mode (which connected
  to 'bridge' network by default)
* Disconnect from 'bridge' network
* Connect to each requested neutron network

The problem is that docker-py doesn't support connect with
specified MAC address [1]. This caused problems on SR-IOV support,
which required to set the MAC address. Therefore, we need to change
to a new workflow:
* Create container with the first requested neutron network
* Connect to the rest of the neutron networks

[1] https://github.com/docker/docker-py/pull/1756

Change-Id: Ib26fc3458c95c3b3d5df9566acdb0a2d28d1eb30
"}]
commit_message:
Set network mode on creating container

This patch changed the workflow to configure the network in
docker. The old workflow is as following:
* Create container with default network_mode (which connected
  to 'bridge' network by default)
* Disconnect from 'bridge' network
* Connect to each requested neutron network

The problem is that docker-py doesn't support connect with
specified MAC address [1]. This caused problems on SR-IOV support,
which required to set the MAC address. Therefore, we need to change
to a new workflow:
* Create container with the first requested neutron network
* Connect to the rest of the neutron networks

[1] https://github.com/docker/docker-py/pull/1756

Change-Id: Ib26fc3458c95c3b3d5df9566acdb0a2d28d1eb30

messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2017-11-20 03:10:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2017-11-25 21:32:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2017-11-27 08:01:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2017-11-27 10:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-20 03:10:22.000000000', 'message': 'Allow duplicated container name by default

In before, the default config disallow duplicated name within
tenant. This is a bad default because zun auto-generate container
name if it is not specified. It is possible that the same name
is generated twice which causes failure. This makes our API
unpredictable which is not a good practice. Therefore, we changed
the default to allow duplicated name.

Change-Id: Ic0f4d1279c0822aceac9e1983dc500afe9834a59
'}]
commit_message:
Allow duplicated container name by default

In before, the default config disallow duplicated name within
tenant. This is a bad default because zun auto-generate container
name if it is not specified. It is possible that the same name
is generated twice which causes failure. This makes our API
unpredictable which is not a good practice. Therefore, we changed
the default to allow duplicated name.

Change-Id: Ic0f4d1279c0822aceac9e1983dc500afe9834a59

commit_message:
Restore tags inside the main playbook

This modification reintroduces the tags for all the task inside the main
playbooks quickstart-extras-*.yml.
This is related to the tags topic [1] and is meant for developers who
wants to have atomic access to each step of the deployment.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1657415

Change-Id: Icd645ee9003bafb8988a6430280ab4b7ad5ff34f

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 18:54:47.000000000', 'message': 'Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

Change-Id: I843c4e104c6d694074899912cbdf0332bfcf2a26
'}]
commit_message:
Align tox_install.sh with other projects

The tox_install.sh here behaves a bit differently than the others, which
is causing some problems when trying to rework some of the shared gate
jobs.

Align it to the form used in other repos.

Change-Id: I843c4e104c6d694074899912cbdf0332bfcf2a26

commit_message:
Set the default CephAnsiblePlaybook to use into the env files

This will make sure that any scale up attempt is executed using
the site-docker.yml playbook.

Change-Id: I54796b70d4dbb26c41651171fae937a50852ef7d
Closes-Bug: #1734114

commit_message:
Define swift_proxy_port for trove

Trove needs to access swift_proxy_port, which was currently
only defined in swift_all, and therefore undefined for trove.

Change-Id: I9bf893f1f047ea1896a64da12909faeac2c1c126

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-27 10:11:16.000000000', 'message': 'Stop masking VIP allocate neutron errors

Previously the neutron network driver was masking the actual error being
returned from neutron while doing a VIP port allocation.
This patch will pass through the neutron error to the user if it is
an API ready exception giving the user more useful information about the
error neutron is reporting. For example that the requested VIP address is
already allocated.

Change-Id: Ic327b06ff9ccf9ae0c9931a8e6569c20d03c4a79
Closes-Bug: #1714593
Story: 1714593
Task: 5005
(cherry picked from commit c1afc1586394333b71da2678568ce5696e0d189d)
'}]
commit_message:
Stop masking VIP allocate neutron errors

Previously the neutron network driver was masking the actual error being
returned from neutron while doing a VIP port allocation.
This patch will pass through the neutron error to the user if it is
an API ready exception giving the user more useful information about the
error neutron is reporting. For example that the requested VIP address is
already allocated.

Change-Id: Ic327b06ff9ccf9ae0c9931a8e6569c20d03c4a79
Closes-Bug: #1714593
Story: 1714593
Task: 5005
(cherry picked from commit c1afc1586394333b71da2678568ce5696e0d189d)

commit_message:
Fix keepalived check script

The keepalived check script would indicate that the amphora was not healthy
if the listener had not yet been created. This change fixes this allowing
the VIP to come up and master election to complete at load balancer create
time.

(cherry picked from commit 29051f012cf8db550c2c133353258f4d64ddb8d7)
Change-Id: Icb393e3ec33fee3d9a4ca89eb4ab338c53fc2d9d
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>

subject: Rename 'remove' to 'reset' in Quota API
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6469, 'name': 'Carlos Gonçalves', 'display_name': 'Carlos Goncalves', 'email': 'cgoncalves@redhat.com', 'username': 'cgoncalves'}, {'_account_id': 6579, 'name': 'Nir Magnezi', 'email': 'nmagnezi@redhat.com', 'username': 'nmagnezi'}, {'_account_id': 10273, 'name': 'Adam Harwell', 'email': 'flux.adam@gmail.com', 'username': 'rm_you'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27303, 'name': 'Bar Elharar', 'email': 'elhararb@gmail.com', 'username': 'elhararb'}]

[{'account_id': 25239, 'date': '2017-11-22 22:54:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25239, 'date': '2017-11-22 22:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27303, 'date': '2017-11-22 23:13:54.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to quota_support'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2017-11-23 11:37:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As discussed on IRC, I agree with the renaming.

I would though even suggest going a step further and move "DELETE /v2.0/lbaas/quotas/<id>" to "PUT /v2.0/lbaas/quotas/<id>/reset". Otherwise it might also cause confusion to users as it would still be a HTTP DELETE action.'}, {'account_id': 27303, 'date': '2017-11-23 15:34:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Carlos, thank you for your suggestion. I agree there could several possible approaches to fix this.
I have added it in the description in the related story: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2001295'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2017-11-27 13:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This is one of those things I think we should discuss in the weekly meeting.'}, {'account_id': 25239, 'date': '2017-11-27 14:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2017-11-27 19:50:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

This is fine as it does not affect the API, just documentation.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2017-11-27 22:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Fine by me.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 22:54:05.000000000', 'message': "Rename 'remove' to 'reset' in Quota API

The name of the API remove quota is misleading, since
it does not remove the quota at all, but resets it to
its default value.

This patch is limited to the title of the call in v2,
and it does not modify the REST API in any way.

Change-Id: Idfb1f3c3fe90d71434d0bb6a973e146ea3dea67c
"}, {'created': '2017-11-22 22:59:49.000000000', 'message': "Rename 'remove' to 'reset' in Quota API

The name of the remove_quota API call is misleading.
The real purpose of this call is to reset the quota
to its default value, not to remove it.

This patch is limited to the title of the call in v2,
and it does not modify the REST API in any way.

Change-Id: Idfb1f3c3fe90d71434d0bb6a973e146ea3dea67c
"}, {'created': '2017-11-27 14:53:52.000000000', 'message': "Rename 'remove' to 'reset' in Quota API

The name of the remove_quota API call is misleading.
The real purpose of this call is to reset the quota
to its default value, not to remove it.

This patch is limited to the title of the call in v2,
and it does not modify the REST API in any way.

Task: 5868
Story: 2001295

Change-Id: Idfb1f3c3fe90d71434d0bb6a973e146ea3dea67c
"}]
commit_message:
Rename 'remove' to 'reset' in Quota API

The name of the remove_quota API call is misleading.
The real purpose of this call is to reset the quota
to its default value, not to remove it.

This patch is limited to the title of the call in v2,
and it does not modify the REST API in any way.

Task: 5868
Story: 2001295

Change-Id: Idfb1f3c3fe90d71434d0bb6a973e146ea3dea67c

commit_message:
Use the local collector to bootstrap deployed servers

os-collect-config is already configured to use json files in
/var/lib/os-collect-config/local-data/ as a data source, so this can
be used in the deployed-server get-occ-config.sh to copy in the
required json to generate the required os-collect-config.conf.

Co-Authored-By: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1679705
Change-Id: Ibde9e6bf360277d4ff64f66d637a5c7f0360e754
(cherry picked from commit 5e934cd9b8b17c62a2f8729a1e6f50b9b9001ff8)

commit_message:
Implement query param schema for fping index

GET fping API accept query param to filter the
instance to ping.
This commit adds json schema to validate the valid
query parameters.

There is no change in API behaviour and additionalProperties
is kept True for backward compatibility.

Partially implements blueprint json-schema-validation-for-query-param

Change-Id: Iaba33625071b9146930c2821750068f3a5a35b12

This was discussed at length during the Queens PTG in Denver.
Afterwords, we spent time during a weekly meeting recapping the
discussion with folks who couldn't attend [0]. Based on the new
direction of system scoping [1], I think it is safe to remove this
from the specs repository.

[0] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/keystone/2017/keystone.2017-09-26-18.00.log.html#l-70

Change-Id: I2176807e03a3837e077873b19858da3d5f70f4e1
"}]
commit_message:
Remove role check from middleware from specs

This was discussed at length during the Queens PTG in Denver.
Afterwords, we spent time during a weekly meeting recapping the
discussion with folks who couldn't attend [0]. Based on the new
direction of system scoping [1], I think it is safe to remove this
from the specs repository.

[0] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/keystone/2017/keystone.2017-09-26-18.00.log.html#l-70
[1] https://trello.com/b/bpWycnwa/policy-roadmap

Change-Id: I2176807e03a3837e077873b19858da3d5f70f4e1

commit_message:
Undercloud: Add router for IPv6 ctlplane subnet

A router is needed so that router advertisements are send out for
the subnet. Also add the router plugin and start the l3 agent
which are responsible for the router handling.

Change-Id: I2c7c6232d00a11f550ad186f94ce628090ec93ed

commit_message:
Implement query param schema for delete assisted vol

DELETE assisted_volume_snapshots API accept 'delete_info'
query param.

This commit adds json schema to validate the valid
query parameters.

There is no change in API behaviour and additionalProperties
is kept True for backward compatibility.

Partially implements blueprint json-schema-validation-for-query-param

Change-Id: Ie1e81dfdb1e42af87725977c0f9504ea35ca9d70

[{'created': '2017-11-27 11:03:15.000000000', 'message': 'Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: I30123183ad3d4a0078fbb92941b2b8e8aadd6d1c
Closes-Bug: 1734620
'}, {'created': '2017-11-27 11:24:56.000000000', 'message': 'Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: I30123183ad3d4a0078fbb92941b2b8e8aadd6d1c
Closes-Bug: 1734620
'}]
commit_message:
Process client broker requests post bootstrap

Its possible that a remote client unit will present its broker
request prior to the Ceph MON cluster being bootstrapped; ensure
that any client-relation-changed hooks are re-executed after
bootstrap to process any pending broker requests.

Change-Id: I30123183ad3d4a0078fbb92941b2b8e8aadd6d1c
Closes-Bug: 1734620

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-22 09:31:35.000000000', 'message': "Mock creation of ~/.tripleo directory

It's already specifically tested in test_utils.py and was leaving
~/.tripleo directories on developer machines after running the
tests. Randomly failing to create the directory would also sometime
cause other unit tests to fail.

Change-Id: I54c5dfd98a71c2544215ececc61d28cbd17218a6
Closes-Bug: #1732751
Closes-Bug: #1704380
(cherry picked from commit 176349dd3d3dcb2990e5f4afdb56736f18fd823d)
"}]
commit_message:
Mock creation of ~/.tripleo directory

It's already specifically tested in test_utils.py and was leaving
~/.tripleo directories on developer machines after running the
tests. Randomly failing to create the directory would also sometime
cause other unit tests to fail.

Change-Id: I54c5dfd98a71c2544215ececc61d28cbd17218a6
Closes-Bug: #1732751
Closes-Bug: #1704380
(cherry picked from commit 176349dd3d3dcb2990e5f4afdb56736f18fd823d)

commit_message:
Add ProviderSummary.resource_class_names @property

Adds a simple ProviderSummary.resource_class_names @property that
returns a set() of resource class string names for all resources in the
provider summary. This allows a couple locations in the
_alloc_candidates_with_shared() function to be a little more readable.

Change-Id: I5ba492db3e38a3b560443780af82aef5105f13e1

commit_message:
Remove tripleo-buildimage-overcloud-full-centos-7 from gate

- tripleo-buildimage-overcloud-full-centos-7 is non voting for now
- tripleo-buildimage-overcloud-full-centos-7 is not passing now, some
  dependencies (qemu-img-ev) fail to be deployed by bindep.
- will be voting once things are more stable.

Change-Id: Icb5044774fc4aa585d63a7a66d049515722b7be6

commit_message:
Output the location of the overcloud rc file

As the rc file is based on the stack name, it isn't always obvious where
it will be. This change adds to the output at the end of a deploy to let
the user know where it is located.

Change-Id: Ib6723571aa38aeec053bb2e3e7a11b37f725fa80
Closes-Bug: #1733593

commit_message:
Ensure openrc files contain correct keystone version

* Adding a function to ensure correct keystone version
  in the auth_url for the openrc files.

Change-Id: I4ef828ba257729f15c25ed8f790b2799882f908a
Closes-Bug: #1547061

i'm not so sure about this change, i'll let jamie and dean weigh in"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-09 03:29:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

jamie, dean, any chance for a review on this?'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-11-10 23:43:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

If things like region_name is changed, can we detect that and update the cached client?'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-11 00:21:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> If things like region_name is changed, can we detect that and
 > update the cached client?

Technically yes, although I'd argue that there wouldn't be any point. I did a previous patch which made the cache be keyed by region, but effectively from the user perspective the functionality would be exactly the same. Same with updating the cache automatically.

See this paste:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/588870/

Only after explicitly asking for the new client would you get it in the new region. And in some cases keeping both clients sitting around might be useful to you (so you'd give the new one a different name rather than replace).

To actually allow the client itself (the old reference you have) to change automatically would be either very painful (changes to the client libraries or objects internally), or require a wrapper class which itself is connected to the client cache and internally updated whenever the region_name is changed. Your client then would be a client_wrapper object, any function calls on it get passed along to the actual client with decorators that first check if the region is different and swap in the new client to call functions on. This would be far too much work, for something that would likely just confuse people when their existing clients are suddenly in a different region.

Getting rid of the cache, and treating the client_manager as just a multi-client constructor feels the easiest and most sensible approach.

Sorry for going into too much detail, but the idea of automatically updating the client was interesting to think about. :)"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-03-02 23:35:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-03-03 01:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Hi Adrian:

Please correct me if I'm wrong, according your describe and paste content[1], seems you are looking an unify SDK for application that call openstack APIs between different regions, so I think you should use openstacksdk, not openstackclient in your case, you only need to build a new connection with the region you want, that's build-in feature in openstacksdk, refer to [2], openstackclient use openstacksdk for network commands now.

[1]: http://paste.openstack.org/show/588870/
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/openstackclient/network/client.py#L37"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-03-07 02:14:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Hi Adrian:
 > 
 > Please correct me if I'm wrong, according your describe and paste
 > content[1], seems you are looking an unify SDK for application that
 > call openstack APIs between different regions, so I think you
 > should use openstacksdk, not openstackclient in your case, you only
 > need to build a new connection with the region you want, that's
 > build-in feature in openstacksdk, refer to [2], openstackclient use
 > openstacksdk for network commands now.
 > 
 > [1]: http://paste.openstack.org/show/588870/
 > [2]: https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/openstackclient/network/client.py#L37

The reason for this patch is to allow me and others to write multi-region commands for the openstackclient and plugins, which can reuse the client constructor that the openstackclient has (the client_manager). The problem now is that changing that client_manager.region_name values does nothing if you've already created a client for the existing region.

Sure, I could import and use any of the pythonclient libraries or the openstackSDK directly and scope them to the right region, but that is extra work I'd prefer not to have to do when the client_manager has all that built in and returns instances of the clients already. The only problem is that the caching pointlessly holds old versions of the clients once they are created.

This patch is specific to openstackclient, and making it easier to do custom multi-region commandline commands."}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2017-03-07 02:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-09-14 02:05:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-14 03:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

commit_message:
Remove ClientCache

With how keystoneauth1 handles sessions there
is no longer any point in caching the clients.

Caching the client also causes issues where
client_manager.region_name is changed as older
clients which were cached will be in the wrong
region.

This change forces clients to be rebuilt fresh
every time with no real performance impact.

Change-Id: Ifc17872a37a21397349f2162dac43ff96a37e7e8
Closes-Bug: #1669615

why not change the policy to allow admin_or_owner?'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-07-23 00:02:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That looks like it would only work for create.

The problem is more list and delete. List doesn't filter by default, so owner wouldn't do anything useful 
as unless we can enforce that filter non-admins will see other user credentials. Not to mention this will by default return your secret rather than just the id of the credential, which we should avoid.

Then to delete you need an id, and you need to list to get that id, but if we let a user delete any id, that is unsafe as delete also does not filter by user_id.

A separate plugin + endpoints would define clear and safe user functionality without altering existing functionality or code. It also allow us to handle generation code for totp credentials server side so a user can optionally ask for a totp secret rather than generate one themselves."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-07-25 23:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-26 03:24:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-keystone-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/05/345705/2/check/gate-keystone-specs-docs/b005af3//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 6m 50s
- gate-keystone-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/05/345705/2/check/gate-keystone-specs-python27/da53a3b/ : SUCCESS in 4m 24s'}, {'account_id': 6804, 'date': '2016-08-26 22:23:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-08-28 23:49:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > why not change the policy to allow admin_or_owner?

Just going back over this and I have to admit, I'm not entirely sure why I thought this wasn't easily doable with policy changes for list. What code was I looking at? My apologises Steve.

The delete and get cases though are still a little weird as they need something like this:
https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/contrib/ec2/controllers.py#L363

That check, plus possible server side generation of the TOTP secret make the contrib module for TOTP credentials useful.

I assume adding such a check to the main credentials endpoints isn't really a good idea (even with 'ignore if admin'), and we probably don't want TOTP secret creation logic in the generic credential code anyway.

I could be missing something/misreading the code and policy syntax very easily, so if there is a better way I'm all for it."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-08-29 00:09:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I understand there is a need for different authorization for TOTP. However, I think there is a simpler way to do it than creating new API entries just for changing the policy rule. See my comment inline'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-17 00:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > I understand there is a need for different authorization for TOTP.
 > However, I think there is a simpler way to do it than creating new
 > API entries just for changing the policy rule. See my comment
 > inline

The need for a new set of APIs is two fold.

Authorisation is a core part of that, because we shouldn't alter the current credentials endpoint, as it makes sense to keep those admin only. Credentials are pretty much just a key value pairing, some type, to some blob (secret). There are no validation checks, nothing that actually confirms what you are adding will work for the given type. This could mean that if any user is allowed to add a cert, or totp, or ec2 credential that doesn't match the right format... something could break. This is why I think keeping the core credentials endpoints as they are is probably a good idea, they are too powerful and unlimited.

The second reason is that I would like to include TOTP secret generation code on the server, such that a user could request a secret rather than generating one themselves and uploading it. It makes more sense for this to be in it's own little module (like EC2 creds), where we can safely add logic and code without altering or polluting the existing credentials endpoints with unneeded functionality. Or if we want to enforce a minimum secret length/strength for TOTP, we really shouldn't be adding validation logic to the credentials core endpoints.

There are other ways to solve this, sure, but those involve a redo or refactor of the current credentials endpoints, which is probably not a good idea right now. The new APIs would be simple enough, and in the process I could cut out and reuse some of the logic that will be shared with the EC2 credential controllers. This would also then in future allow the addition of cert credential APIs should we want them (or other credential types), which also have their own validation or type specific functionality."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2016-11-18 03:11:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Hi Adrian, just a couple question/concerns inline. Let me know if they make sense or hit me up in #openstack-keystone.'}, {'account_id': 6804, 'date': '2016-11-18 15:54:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18666, 'date': '2016-11-19 01:56:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-20 21:55:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-20 23:42:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-20 23:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

- gate-keystone-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/05/345705/9/check/gate-keystone-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/597c68b/ : SUCCESS in 1m 34s'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2016-11-21 21:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Thanks for respinning, Adrian. I have a few more comments inline. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6804, 'date': '2016-11-21 22:56:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:36:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)

The primary reason I have for wanting a new API is that I'm not sure cert, TOTP, and EC2 actually fit under the same umbrella at all (what even is the 'cert' credential type?). 

What we've done is shoehorn them into the same place because the credentials database model allows us a really easy key:value store in the form of type:blob. Each of the types stores data in that blob entirely differently to the point that it may as well be a new database model. The reason I do think it makes sense is because we never really need to index by the blob content. Only by owner and the type.

The power of allowing credentials as just a key:value store is also a lot of flexibility which I admit I've been making use of as it lets me test out different types of authentication models really easily. As an admin I can insert new types of credential and then write code in keystone which makes use of that.

The problem though is that really each type needs different parameters at creation or different actions and APIs.

At present EC2 credentials can't be uploaded, only created, so inserting a EC2 credential via the actual credential endpoints could easily break things if it was in the wrong format. The create command doesn't take parameters, it just creates and responds with the credential.

This is what a EC2 credential looks like:
blob = {'access': uuid.uuid4().hex,
        'secret': uuid.uuid4().hex,
        'trust_id': request.context.trust_id}


TOTP really should have a create command (generate and return a secret), and then a follow up which is activate (supply a passcode), which actually then enables the TOTP credential for use.
Delete should also require a passcode which must be valid for the secret in question.

This is what a TOTP credential looks like right now:
blob = "GEZDGNBVGY3TQOJQGEZDGNBVGY"

What TOTP should really look like:
blob = {'secret': 'GEZDGNBVGY3TQOJQGEZDGNBVGY',
        'enabled': False}


I don't really think a single credentials API is truly sufficient to convey and allow this much variation between the types, nor allow specialised creation functionality, different parameters for delete, or commands like activate for TOTP.

If we did make this all one API, it would either be a giant mess, or a VERY carefully constructed setup with plugins for each type of credential.

That got longer than I intended... but it answers some questions. :)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:38:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

let's focus on getting MFA working as approved first, then let's tackle this problem"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-12-07 04:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Agreed. How we do the new per user rules and MFA stuff will change how we want to approach user management.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2016-12-07 22:10:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:
